campaign.story:
That house on the outskirts of town, sitting empty behind a crumbling wall. The one people whisper about. The one that has gone unlived in for years. Sometimes a few hearty souls creep in, it is said, to see what treasures or secrets they can find. Most find nothing—just an empty old house. Some return shaken. A few don’t return at all.
You’ve seen this house before. If not in this city, then in some other. You’ve heard the rumors—and if you haven’t, well, someday they’ll find you.
What happens to a house when it sits alone for so many long years? What jealousies and hatreds does it quietly nurture? What whispers echo through its empty hallways? What waits, crouched within its dark rooms, hungering for the return of life?
For you.
The Darkest House is a tabletop roleplaying game (RPG) product built from the ground up for online play, with unique features that take advantage of the online environment for an awesome experience. It's compatible with the game you're playing now. In fact, it's made for it! That’s because The Darkest House derives its horror from the bonds, backstories, ideals, loves, and fears your existing characters bring into it. Experiencing it will add depth to your campaign, your party, and your characters—those who come out alive!
Cross the threshold. Explore The Darkest House. The experience will change and challenge your PCs, their party, and your gaming group. And you won't have to wait long: You'll  have everything you need to bring The Darkest House to your campaign in May (with extras and exclusives to follow).
Scroll down to try a preview of The Darkest House!
The Darkest House is a digital product designed specifically to the needs of running and playing games online—and built to take maximum advantage of that mode of play. Think of it like an RPG book reimagined to make the most of the online environment. Every image and map is conveniently shareable and downloadable. Each encounter is formatted to your screen, giving you everything you need in a single view. Text for sharing with the players is easily copied with a single click. A rich network of hyperlinks makes navigation simple and intuitive. The Darkest House is as easy on the GM as the house itself is challenging to the PCs.
Use The Darkest House in conjunction with your preferred online TTRPG platform: run your game on Zoom or Discord, or use a virtual tabletop (VTT) like Roll20 or Astral. Only the GM needs a copy of The Darkest House—like a conventional RPG product, it gives the GM the information, resources, and tools to run the game, plus loads of handouts, images, and other sharable items to distribute, as appropriate, to the players.
The Darkest House consists of:
The downloadable product, containing the many dozens of rooms of the house itself. This is what the GM will primarily use during play. There’s enough content for many visits to the house, and dozens of hours of play—and through stretch goals the house continues to grow!
 The Darkest House: Secrets of the House in PDF, a GM's guide detailing the House's background, conversion rules, and the House Rules set you'll use as your PCs explore, and try to escape from, the Darkest House.
 The Darkest House Player's Guide in PDF, which gives players the character conversion rules and everything they need to explore (and try to escape from) the Darkest House.
To use The Darkest House, the GM will need a desktop or laptop computer running macOS or Windows and a broadband internet connection. Scroll down to try a preview of The Darkest House.
How It Works
Although The Darkest House is a completely new type of product, you'll use it in basically the same way you use a typical RPG book or PDF—it's just easier and has a lot more features for online play. You'll still use a VTT or videoconference platform (such as Roll20 or Zoom) to run your game. Your players won't access The Darkest House app itself—like a physical adventure book, it's just for the GM. (You will share The Darkest House Player's Guide PDF, and loads of handouts, maps, and images with them, though.)
Here's an example: Charles normally runs his games using Zoom for audio and video, and Slack for text messaging, sharing JPGs of handouts, and rolling dice. In addition, he has his game books and notes open on his desk beside him, or PDFs and other files open on his computer. When running The Darkest House, he'll use Zoom and Slack the same way, and keep The Darkest House app open on his computer in place of all those books or PDFs. He can share maps, images, and text with just a click or two, pasting them into his Slack channel as the PCs encounter new rooms, creatures, and clues.
LaTia runs her games on Roll20. The Darkest House works the same way in that environment, with one additional advantage: LaTia can set up her encounters in advance, downloading the maps and resources before the game starts and setting them up within Roll20.
Try It!
Want to see how it works? Check out the preview of The Darkest House now for a look at a few of the rooms and features. Download it for either macOS or Windows (below). Open it, have a look at the intro page, and explore as you see fit—or take this little tour:
Click Explore The Darkest House Now on the right side of the intro page and you'll find yourself in the Boundless Room, just one example of the House's many, many rooms.
See the words Pried Up Floorboards on the map? Click them, and the description will open to the right.
Some items aren't tagged on the map. Click The Giggling Ghost at the bottom right of the screen.
Under the first set of boxed text, and click the Copy Text button. Return to this Kickstarter, go into the comments, and paste. That's how easy it is to copy and paste info for the players. Features like these make the most of the online environment—making it an advantage instead of an impediment!
You can also share images and maps just as easily. Go to The Family Portrait and click Download under the handout to download the image, or "Copy Link" to paste the link into a chat or browser window to share it that way. You can do the same with the room map and main illustration.
The portrait holds the secret to escaping this particular room. Click the link to the Interior Courtyard to continue your exploration of the House.
Continue to explore to discover the many ways The Darkest House stands apart from conventional RPG products. This preview of the app is not final and only demonstrates a small portion of The Darkest House. The final product may differ slightly.
That old house that everyone whispers about. That apartment at the end of the hall where no tenant ever stays for long. That strange unit in the station quarters sector, where everything seems a bit off. These are among the many entrances to the Darkest House.
Like an invasive vine or a creeping shadow, the Darkest House insinuates itself into any universe. It is a malignant and primal force, unconcerned with the specifics of the worlds it seeps into. The Darkest House exists in our world—in your world—in any world. Wherever there is hunger, the Darkest House can gain a foothold. It is perfectly happy to take root in your campaign.
Or campaigns. The house draws from the many worlds it touches. It need not pull all its victims from the same setting. Imagine an experience that gathers your favorite characters from different campaigns to work together to survive its horrors. As a product specially designed for online play, scattered gaming groups can come back together for a unique reunion experience.
The Darkest House’s effect on character development and backstory makes it really shine when introduced to existing characters and campaigns. It will influence the quality of play for long after the characters have escaped it. 
Inject the Darkest House into your ongoing campaign as a horror interlude or as a recurring encounter. It works as a standalone one-shot, but there’s far more to the house than that. With many dozens of rooms (and growing, through stretch goals) adding up to 30-50 hours of game play, PCs who escape the house might stumble upon it later, seek it out to further plumb its mysteries, or find themselves drawn into it again to free themselves and their world of its darkness.
The house has many aspects, and there will always be more to discover.
The House System
The Darkest House isn't just compatible with the game you’re already playing—it was made for it! Within The Darkest House, you’ll use the House System. You’ll quickly and easily convert your existing characters (it takes about five minutes) and use those stats while in The Darkest House. Once the PCs emerge, your players will return to their regular setting using their regular character sheets. The House System is a sort of RPG Rosetta Stone, allowing easy translation into and out of any game system—and even letting you bring characters from different games together.
The House System is tailored for tension and terror. With each die roll, the players roll the House Die, which might indicate that the house itself takes an action. Players can call upon the essence of the house while they're within it to turn a failure into a success, but every time they do so they accumulate personal Doom. Escaping the house with the weight of such Doom on their shoulders, characters may find themselves scarred, cursed, or haunted in all manner of disturbing ways, carrying remnants of their experience back into their home campaigns long after they've left.
It's possible to launch a campaign centered around the Darkest House. But that's not what the house wants. It is strongest when it reaches into an ongoing campaign to test and challenge existing characters. That’s because events in the Darkest House will change characters and alter the campaign setting. The house gets its metaphorical claws into those that cross its threshold, and the house itself changes based on who those characters are, who they have loved, who they have hated, and where they have been. Characters who explore the house and make it back out are never quite the same.
Want even deeper mysteries? More secrets? More dangers? The Devoured Halls is a separate portion of the Darkest House, with its own rooms, its own secret entrance and exit, and its own mysteries to uncover. Within this section of the house, characters might discover that perhaps the house isn't fully in control of itself… the house itself might be broken. While The Darkest House is a complete package, The Devoured Halls adds its own flavor and offers its own experience in keeping with the rest of the house. It fits in seamlessly and offers additional depth and an entirely new mini story for characters to investigate. 
The Devoured Halls backer level includes the complete Darkest House plus the additional content in the Devoured Halls—a Kickstarter exclusive available only through this campaign. Backing at this level has even more exclusive benefits—you also get:
Monte Cook's secret tour of the Darkest House: In the style of a director's commentary track, Monte takes you on a video tour of the House covering his favorite rooms. He delves into their genesis and inspiration, gives you insights into the lore behind them, and talks about how he's used them in his own games.
The Darkest House digital art book: The Darkest House contains dozens and dozens of illustrations, all as mysterious as they are beautiful. The Art of The Darkest House presents all of them—including illustrations from the Devoured Halls—in beautiful detail. Annotations by Monte and Art Director Bear Weiter accompany many of the illustrations, and several also include details or alternate versions calling out their secrets and hidden features.
Monte Cook has designed many RPGs over his 30+ year career, including Dungeons & Dragons 3rd Edition, the Cypher System, Numenera, and Invisible Sun. He wanted to share why he he was inspired to create The Darkest House, and what design decisions he made. Check out his insights below.
I'm Monte Cook, and I created and designed the Darkest House. I've been using the essence of it in various campaigns for years, and I thought I'd take a moment to describe why I designed it the way I have, and hopefully why you'll find it intriguing and interesting as well.
Why Focus on Online Gaming?
At Monte Cook Games, we're spread out all across the continent. We've been regularly playing RPGs on Zoom or Roll20 since well before the pandemic, as of course many gamers have. In the 21st Century, gaming online has become a standard feature of tabletop games, and the last year or so has accelerated that aspect of running and playing games to an incredible degree. Gaming online has its own challenges, but it has its own strengths as well. As a designer, I've been pondering how to not just focus on the needs of online play, but to in fact embrace online play, bringing the aspects of gaming that it does particularly well to the fore. The ability to share art, to share text, and to send individual players direct messages are just some of the things that The Darkest House not just enables but shines a spotlight upon. Meanwhile, the difficulties of online gaming, such as managing lots of information, maintaining a mood, and dealing with cumbersome mechanics are all facets of the experience that the Darkest House eases.
Why Focus on Cross-System Play?
One of the things that's been true of a lot of us over the last year is a desire to reconnect with old pals or faraway friends. If your primary means of socializing is a video conference, people a thousand miles away are no farther away than those up the street. Still, talking to your friends through a computer screen can sometimes be hard. With all the additional barriers that online gaming can create, why should game systems add another?
The Darkest House offers an easy way to quickly convert the essence of any character from any system into a simple but interesting character who operates within the house's own, specific rules, tailored to the experiences within. My dream is that people will use The Darkest House as an excuse to rekindle that lapsed campaign with their old gaming group separated by time and distance, regardless of what system was being used. Or, perhaps even more exciting, the GM who's got a selection of friends who never regularly game together and use different systems can take their existing characters, temporarily convert them to the House System, and all go on an exciting and challenging (or horrifying) adventure together.
I believe that RPGs bring people together, and I hope that The Darkest House brings people together who might not otherwise get to easily enjoy each other's company. (And what better way to rekindle old bonds than in absolute terror?) 
Why a Haunted House?
Inspired by games like Kitty Horrowshow's Anatomy, books like Mark Z. Danielewski's House of Leaves, and films like Stanley Kubrick's The Shining, I realized that the horror genre and haunted houses in particular offer unique opportunities to shine a light on characters, and RPGs are all about characters. I wanted to create an adventure that would deepen the characters even as it put them through their paces.
When PCs enter the Darkest House, they'll find far more than just a haunted house. It is a crucible of sorts, where their mettle and their minds will be tested. Those who fall short will suffer heavy consequences. Those who can hold their own, however, emerge more deeply developed with a greater insight into their world, their companions, and most of all themselves. The Darkest House forces players to think about their characters' deepest fears, dreams, their families, and their faith in their friends. Encounters are designed to focus less on damage dealt or resources used and more on the personalities, past experiences, and fundamental truths of a character. And if a character is lacking any of those, the Darkest House will enable the GM and players to work together to create them, or flesh them out, as needed.
If you've read this far, you've very likely picked up on the fact that within the Darkest House, it's the house itself that is the enemy. I have long had a fascination with fictional places with a mind or an essence all their own. And when that essence evolves over a long period of loneliness, neglect, and exposure to darkness and suffering, it makes for a truly unique "villain" far different than any ghost, specter, or demon could ever hope to be. And if that location, that house, grows and seeps in both space and time, devouring the very locations and loved ones important to those that cross its doorstep, well... I don't want to get into spoiler territory. Let's just say, if nothing else, The Darkest House certainly offers some unique experiences that will create stories your players will be talking about for years to come.

updates.update_userinfo: The House Is Ready to Enter Your World—and It’s Hungry!
Are You Ready to Enter the House?
The Campaign Is Over, and the House Is Appeased … for Now
updates.update_content:
The house invited you in … and you entered.
The house hungered … and you fed it.
The house was alone … and you joined it.
The house still hates you.

updates.update_userinfo: Graphics Unlocked! But the House Has Other Concerns...
updates.update_content:
You have once again unlocked a stretch goal, and your games will now be graced by a suite of online graphics including backgrounds, wallpapers, and streaming frames.
But the house does not care about that. The house is hungry. It wants to grow. It wants you to feed it!
At $205,000, the house will grow once more. As it has before, it will form new rooms—or take them from the worlds it invades. It will gain roughly three new rooms, and The Devoured Halls will expand by at least one room as well.

updates.update_userinfo: The House Has Grown Again! (Plus New Art!)
updates.update_content:
Once again the house has grown. Your support has brought new rooms into being. This is perhaps fortunate for you, as your reward grows and you gain even more gameplay in the house. But it’s less fortunate for anyone who cherished those rooms in their own worlds. Especially if they were in them at the time.
What is next?
The Darkest House is, of course, optimized for gaming online. At $190,000 we’ll unlock a suite of items to dress up your online game. Things like a set of video backgrounds for games played on Zoom or similar platforms, frames and templates for streamed games, wallpapers, and so on.  Unlike most of our other goals, these digital files won’t be part of the product itself, but rather exclusive rewards for Kickstarter backers. They aren’t part of gameplay, but like the décor in your in-person game space, they’ll make your game just a bit more immersive, atmospheric, and fun.

updates.update_userinfo: The House Has Grown Again, but It Is Never Enough…
updates.update_content:
The House that Hungers: that’s another name by which the Darkest House is known. Its appetite for your dreams and nightmares can never be stated. It has many rooms, but they are never enough for it.
Thanks to your support, the house has once again grown. It is bigger, home to more horror, and so is your reward for backing this campaign. The Devoured Halls have grown as well.
What you have accomplished, though, is not without cost. The house doesn’t just make rooms. It finds them and takes them. You have given the house new rooms, but your gain is someone’s loss. Those rooms have been stolen from someone, somewhere.

updates.update_userinfo: Seminar Unlocked! Now the House Hungers Again!
updates.update_content:
The house is full of unexpected truths. Few of them are as astonishing as your success in driving us to another stretch goal so quickly after we hit the last one!
The seminar with Monte is unlocked. Monte will share his secrets and best practices for making the most of your experience running The Darkest House. You'll get lots of tips and tricks for a game your players—for better or worse!—will never forget. 
The house was quiet as we reached this goal, but it has felt the growing presence of more backers. It stirs. Its hunger reasserts itself. It wants more—it wants to bring it more.

The house has called to you. It is hungry; it wants to grow.
And you heard its call. You answered. You brought it new backers and new worlds. And the house has grown accordingly. Over the past several days we have hit not one but two stretch goals, and the house’s appetite has, for the moment at least, quieted.
If it sleeps, however briefly, perhaps it is wise that we should let it rest. So we’ll ignore its hunger for a while at least. At $150,000, we will add a video seminar to your rewards, led by Monte himself. GMing The Darkest House is, in many ways, much like running any horror game online. But there are many tricks and best practices for getting the absolute most out of it—for really immersing your players in the experience, and maximizing the impact on their characters and your campaign. With Monte’s insights, you’ll give your players an experience they’ll never forget!

updates.update_userinfo: GM Tools Added! What Does the House Do Next?
updates.update_content:
Everything about The Darkest House is designed to optimize the GM’s experience when running games online. With this latest stretch goal reached, you've unlocked  a suite of GM tools that will make The Darkest House even easier to run.
But that helps you, the GM. The house itself is hardly satisfied with this outcome.
It has grown several times since this campaign launched, but it is not enough for the House that Hungers. It is never enough. The house wants to grow, again and again, becoming more dangerous and more frightening.

campaign.story:
CLICCA QUI PER VISUALIZZARE IL TESTO DELLA CAMPAGNA IN ITALIANO
Visit our STORE and GET A COPY NOW!!
FARSIGHT is a pen & paper role-playing game designed to bring science fiction to your table, allowing you to explore pristine worlds, roam the cosmos, and confront with unknown species, alien civilizations and prodigious technologies. Well, provided you can survive the dangers lurking just beyond the edge of the known!
Both in ENGLISH and ITALIAN, plus a bunch of FREE CONTENT!!
Produced by Lightfish Games during years of design and playtest, FARSIGHT is finally ready to project players into the future!
Its game system, evolved from the 5th edition of the most popular rpg of all time, is simple and easy to learn, but capable of giving you all the depth and details that science fiction demands.
With an extremely flexible character-building system, players will be able to create the heroes they want and forge their own destiny, while game masters will have at their disposal fine-tuned tools for creating endless worlds for their adventures and campaigns.
The game places an emphasis on the far future and the ultimate frontier of sci-fi that is space exploration, but it's designed to allow you to shape the setting to suit your style and preferences: from the most epic space-opera to the darker cyberpunk or post-apocalypse!
If you have always wanted to explore the future in its endless possibilities, FARSIGHT RPG is the game you've been waiting for!
FARSIGHT RPG will be available in two languages (English or Italian), thanks to the joined efforts of professional writers and translators.
At the end of the campaign you will be sent a survey to provide your address and select your preferred language.
We are open to collaborations to localize the game in other languages, contact us!
All pictures are for illustraton purpose. Final products may vary due to product enhancement.
Other Add-ons will be added if we hit their stretch golas
If you’ve already selected a reward tier but are still interested in adding some extra items without changing your pledge level, follow the instructions below.
Click the “Manage your Pledge” button on the project’s page.
Edit your pledge amount adding the extra cost of the add-on(s) you want.
Confirm and save your pledge, without changing  the tier of your original pledge.
After the end of the campaign you will receive a survey to your Kickstarter e-mail, to confirm your address and to introduce you to the pledge manager. The pledge manager will enable you to choose your add-ons, to add in some more if you want, and of course to change your selection later.
Please note: If you select some physical add-ons starting from a PDF only pledge, you'll be charged for shipping fees. Add-ons may also increase the weight of your pledge and as a result the shipping costs (see the SHIPPING section below for more details).
Stretch Goals will expand the book contents, provide adventures and additional exlusive materials, and more! But we need your support to make this happen! Help us unlocking as many stretch goals as possible! Share the project with your friends and on social media to help us grow Farsight RPG!
FARSIGHT RPG is based on the 5E EVOLVED game system, a carefully designed adaptation of the 5th edition rules of the world's most popular RPG to science fiction. But don’t get it wrong, it is not a simple hack!
While retaining the essential style of 5E, the 5E EVOLVED implements new basic mechanics, major changes and several features designed to best fit a more sci-fi oriented game style, going as far as to change the canonical ability scores and even to abandon the iconic d20 by changing the basic ability check mechanic (WHAT? Well, yes).
But it doesn’t stop there! Here's some key features:

 Double twelve craziness: Instead of using a single dice (d20) to perform most checks, you will use two twelve-sided dice (2d12). Such a roll creates variety in the outcomes, with a wide range of exploits and setbacks instead of simple critical successes or failures. But don’t think that’s all: advantage/disadvantage, EDGE Cards and other new mechanics will bring bustle and fun on your table!

 Fully customizable characters: Character creation and progression is handled in a modular and versatile way, allowing players to fully customize their characters
Several playable species and lots of different backgrounds.
Three fully customizable classes: the tough DELTA, the reliable SIGMA and the enigmatic PSI.
 Characters who grow with the story: Gain fame and wealth, weave important connections, or instead mess with the wrong people and fall into misfortune! Interludes in between adventures will allow characters to use their “down-time” to pursue their personal goals, to build relationships, work, trade, do research or simply to recover.

 Tactical and deadly combat: Combat is frenetic and merciless. Surely you are heroes, but weapons are deadly and enemies are fighting for their lives as much as you are. Strategy is key: cover, distance, position, weaponry. All of this and countless other tactical choices can make the difference between victory and defeat.
Tactic and strategy are the key to survive. Well you will also need gear, weapons... and luck!
 Gear, vehicles & starships: Can a sci-fi game don’t take into account technology in all its applications? Of course not! You'll have advanced and customizable weapons, armors and tech gear of all kind, and specific rules to create and customize any kind of means of transport, from the smallest planetary vehicle to the most huge starship!
An old and rusty spaceship is better than no spaceship at all... Well, maybe.
And if you are wondering, yes, all the 5E EVOLVED core system is released under OGL! So, if you want to learn more about it, come visit us on our WEBSITE!
Farsight RPG is designed to adapt to any sci-fi setting you want, but its main focus is the ultimate frontier of science fiction: space exploration. 
To give you a glimpse of these frontiers, the Corebook will include an introduction to Chronicles of the Edge, a space opera setting that we hope to expand with your help, through a series of modules and adventures unlockable as stretch goals! Here’s a brief presentation of what awaits you on the verge of the Known Space!
Centuries ago, the Collapse forced the Union to retreat to the Central Systems, forsaking large portions of the Orion Arm.  After an era of oblivion, the now called Outskirts are finally slowly re-flourishing under the influence of new interstellar nations.
The 79 Suns Confederation claims the title of heir to the ancient Union while the Nargor Empire expands its domain by ensuring protection and civilization under an iron fist. Meantime, the traders of the Arkead Cross roam the old stellar routes seeking for deals and the envoys of the misterious Concordate bring reason and aid wherever they can.
While the Known Space is shaken by tensions and turmoils, remote planets and unreached frontiers await to be explored. Artifacts emerge from ancient times, forgotten mysteries awaits to be revealed and unknown threats lurk just beyond the Edge, where every knowledge fades into the depths of uncharted space.

PRODUCTION GUARANTEES 
Our suppliers guarantee quality and speed of delivery. Volume and add-ons will soon be ready to go to print and feasible delivery times have been estimated. If, on receiving your order, you should find that any items are damaged or missing, please contact us at lightfishgames[at]gmail.com, attaching photos of any damaged items. We will send you replacements for the missing/damaged items as soon as possible.

REFUND POLICY
Generally we do not offer refunds unless we are totally unable to deliver the project. We will not offer refunds for delays in delivery or changes/adjustments to the game's components, layout, etc. or for damaged components that can be replaced. We will examine all refund requests individually and, at our own unchallengeable discretion, will only refund those that we feel are justified.

DELIVERY DATE
Our current estimation for delivery is Late 2021 - Early 2022. We will not be held responsible for delays imputable to reasons beyond our control, such as local customs / postal services.

DELIVERY ADDRESS
After the campaign is over, you will receive a request to complete a survey, in which you’ll be asked to provide your shipping address. If, after filling out the survey, you should wish to alter your shipping address, please send us a message at lightfishgames[at]gmail.com

UNDELIVERED ITEMS
If a package is not delivered due to an error in information provided by the backer (wrong address, unclaimed package, etc.), the backer may be requested to pay additional shipping fees for the item to be sent again.

UPDATES 
Through this campaign you may receive updates on Lightfish Games's other upcoming projects. We will only email you with relevant updates.

OUR BEST
BY MAKING A PLEDGE ON THIS CAMPAIGN, YOU ACKNOWLEDGE THAT YOU HAVE READ, UNDERSTOOD AND ACCEPTED THE ENTIRE CONTENT OF THIS SECTION. SHOULD ANYTHING UNEXPECTED OCCUR, REST ASSURED THAT WE WILL DO EVERYTHING IN OUR POWER TO DELIVER THE BEST POSSIBLE PRODUCT IN EVERY ASPECT!

campaign.story:
First thing and apology.
I couldn't get this RPG Zine printed, as sadly I don't have a printer. But I've formatted a special version of the PDF that should allow anyone who wishes to print off their very own copy to go in their collection. 
Please take time to check out all the other amazing RPGs on Kickstarter during Zine Quest, they all look amazing!

Now down to business. Here is my story:
Lockdown has been tough on everyone, and people have tried to find different ways to fill their time whilst stuck in their homes. This is what led me to designing and writing Captain's Log.
I was inspired by the classic opening moments of every episode of Star Trek TNG, and those immortal words..
"Captain's Log.."
That always let you know, you were in for an out of this world adventure, and I wanted to simulate the fun and excitement of those missions.

Captain’s Log is a solo journaling RPG where you find yourself in the command of a ship, its crew embarking on a vast mission through space. 
The limits to this mission are defined by your imagination, and the stories you bring to life.
Playing the Captain's Log is simple and offers hours of creative storytelling fun.

Captain's log has two modes:
Campaign
A 50 entry mission journalling adventure where you will be given the scenario outline of each log entry. Each of these entries will journel a mission, a day and event of note onboard your very own ship.
From there it's up to you to decide where the story goes and what twists and turns await the ship and its crew.

Scenario Generation
These are one off scenarios that can just be generated by simply using a 6 sided dice, or failing that the random number sheet located at  the end of this RPG.
This system will see you generate a unique combination that becomes your scenario.
The system will give you:
A location
A Plot Event
A Subplot
Then as with the campaign the rest is up to you. 
These can be played in single stand alone missions, or perhaps you want to chain them together and make another campaign to take your crew on.
 
This project is for anyone who enjoys creative writing.
Or perhaps someone with a simple love of SCI-FI, who doesn’t know just how creative they can be.
The results of your ‘Captain’s Log’ can be as public or as private, as long or as short as you decide. Writing each entry should be a way to challenge yourself into being creative. You might expand characters and plots over the full campaign, or might just take it one scenario at a time and see where you take your adventure.

This RPG can be played however you want, and I encourage you to be creative. 
But every new scenario dictates an adventure, a fresh scenario for you to bring to life.
Then with each entry you make the world around you and your characters will grow, becoming ever more vivid as you journal the history of your ship, and it’s colourful crew.
To start the campaign:
You pick your crew
You design your ship
You create new alien races
You create a nemesis, and give them a back story
You decide your ships mission
Perhaps you'll borrow ideas from mainstream SCI-FI? Or Mix multiple films and shows together to create a new larger expanded universe?

You'll decide how your adventure unfolds.
You are the Captain, and this is the Captain’s Log.


My name is Matt and I live in Leeds, and I own and play more tabletop games than I should admit. You can find me on Instagram  HERE 
I'll be honest I was undecided as to if I would ever complete this RPG, let alone share it with others. From my initial idea for the RPG I've been plagued with self doubt about how this would be received, and visions of having to refund the small amount of people who actually backed it.
But this isn't about failure, this is about creating something I'm proud of and sending it out into the world for the purpose of saying I did. Like this RPG it's about being creative to challenge yourself. So now I can turn round and say I created something. So if it turns out only 1 person plays this campaign after the Kickstarter is over, that for me is still a success.

I wish everyone good health, and a positive future in this dark time.
And a big THANK YOU for everyone who took time to look at this project.
And another even bigger THANK YOU to anyone who backed it.
I hope you enjoy it as much as I did designing it.
THANK YOU

campaign.story:
Reliquary is a tabletop roleplaying game about wanderers exploring a vast megastructure tens of millions of years in the future. 
Uncover buried temples to forgotten gods, traverse endless staircases through the megastructure’s strata, and push your luck as you delve deeper in search of powerful relics to help your society survive.
Reliquary is a GM-less game of exploration and collaborative world-building. The last vestiges of humanity are spread out across the Coil—a megastructure built over the course of multiple lost civilizations. 2-4 players will build a Coil unique to your play session and then search the remains of what they build. Reliquary is designed to be played either as a one-shot or as a longer campaign as you explore multiple layers of the Coil.
This game is inspired by the brutalist environments of the game NaissanceE and the manga BLAME! as well as the weird architecture found in the art of H.R. Giger and Zdislaw Beksinski.

Cover details and design subject to change. Art by Juan Ochoa.


The Coil is made up of seemingly endless strata—overlapping layers of ancient buildings, artifacts, and machines. One strata may house an entire culture, while another is an uncanny beast’s personal hunting grounds.
You live in the city of Vasq—the only major human settlement known to you—and the Prytanium will always pay for maps, data, and relics from past civilizations. Players create Wanderers to try and deliver them, motivated by duty, honor, or profit.
In progress layout mockup: design and text not final.
In each play session, players will build their own unique version of the Coil by creating ideas for locations, spaced out on the table to create a map. These locations, situated around the home city of Vasq, create one strata of the Coil. Players will answer additional questions about their strata and about Vasq itself to give it their own flavor.
Each player also creates a Wanderer and chooses a Perspective—answering unique prompts through which details can be added to the world. Wanderers are our player characters, and discoveries will be interpreted through their eyes.
Play consists of moving between locations to explore them, interpreting what these locations hold based on playing card suits and values, and rolling dice to salvage supplies or information. Players will encounter new cultures, signs of past civilizations, artificial landmarks, and hostile entities lurking among the ancient machines.
Art by Thomas Novosel
Players manage a dice pool representing the resources available to them, choosing how many dice to risk when they set out to a nearby location. Each location contains a chance to acquire supplies as well as powerful Relic Dice that will help keep their society afloat. As players uncover Relics and explore locations, they'll build a timeline of the Eons of humanity, assigning their discoveries to the timeline to uncover the Coil's vast history.
Art by Thomas Novosel

 A surreal, far-future, brutalist world: The Coil’s strata could go on forever and wait to be explored.
 Clean, simple rules: Simple mechanics allow you to bring depth and detail to the world your characters are exploring.
 Emergent storytelling: Players work together to create the Coil and populate its enigmatic places. No GM or preparation needed.
 Millions of years of history: Create and recreate eons of human—and inhuman—civilization.
In progress layout mockup: design and text not final. Interior art by Juan Ochoa.
 Digital Backers will receive a PDF file of the game.
 Physical Backers will receive a 8.5x5.5" saddle-stitched printed zine of the game as well as a PDF copy.
 Thematic Trilogy Backers will receive the physical and digital versions of Reliquary, as well as two other games that are very thematically connected: Palimpsest and Apotheosis. Both deal with the change in civilization over long periods of time, and are great games to play in tandem with Reliquary to create even more in-depth settings.
 Deluxe Backers will receive all of the above, but your physical copy of Reliquary will be signed, with a personal note included. I'll also write out on index cards 10 custom locations for your game.
Stretch Goals:
UNLOCKED - At $3K I can commission 3-4 more pieces of art for the book from Thomas Novosel to help bring the setting of the Coil to life even more. 

Shipping
Orders will ship weekly in batches per received surveys until they're all out the door. I expect delivery to begin in June 2021.
US orders of the physical zine will ship USPS Media Mail, at $5.
International orders of the physical zine will ship at $18.
Contributors to Reliquary include:
 Gordie Murphy, writer and designer (Apotheosis, Mainframe, Palimpsest)
 Thomas Novosel, artist (Runaway Hirelings, Greeblin's Journey)
 Juan Ochoa, artist (After the War, Callisto, Hall of Judgement)
 Tyler Crumrine, editor (Beak, Feather, & Bone)

campaign.story:
Last year, I Kickstarted DM Yourself – a guide for how to play existing 5e adventures/campaigns (such as The Lost Mines of Phandelver or The Dragon of Icespire Peak) solo with a single character, as close to the way they are written as possible.  The campaign funded and reached all of its stretch goals, with the support of over 500 backers,  and has since sold a further 800 copies on DriveThruRPG 
This campaign is for DM Yourselves – a companion volume to the original – which explores a whole range of new techniques to add to your solo play, and introduces ways in which to play published adventures DM-less with one or more friends. 
DM Yourself introduced a new method for solo roleplaying, a way to play all those adventures I had lying around gathering dust. Its goals were:
To be able to play the adventure as close to written as possible, with minimum rule changes or preparation.
To be able to play with a single player character, but without that character needing to be an invincible superhero.
To achieve maximum immersion, so that the experience recreated some of the feel of playing a roleplaying game (rather than just reading-with-dicerolls).
To find a way to deal with the inevitable spoilers and hidden information, so that the player could still experience the story.
To provide a small set of unobtrusive rules to stop the player from cheating or bending the rules (DMing yourself is hard!).
DM Yourselves takes these ideas and techniques further, giving new ways to bring your solo roleplaying fully to life, whether this is with D&D 5e or another RPG system, played out in full detail or just in casual story mode, on your own or with a friend (when neither of you wants to DM).
DM Yourselves will be a 32-page A5 zine with the following content:
Character Creation
DM Yourself balanced the game for a single PC & Sidekick. DM Yourselves will give rules for having more than one Sidekick and/or PC and how to balance accordingly.
PC Default Behaviours and Binding Decisions for Wilderness and Urban adventures.
Gold and Equipment for PCs/Sidekicks starting at higher levels.
Multiplayer Solo/DM-less Play
DM-less Duet (and general DM-less play). How to play solo together – for when nobody wants to DM or bother with the prep.
Autonomous Sidekicks and PCs
Emulate Sidekicks with depth and their own agenda and flashes of brilliance – “Watch this!” (alignment, secrets, goals, loyalty, suggestions, tricks, moments of inspiration). This means that sometimes your Sidekick may not do exactly what you want (and other times they may do more than you thought possible) – just like another player.
If you want to use DM Yourselves as a way to practice your DM skills, you can even go one step further and emulate the main PC as well as the Sidekick.
More Tips for Solo Play
Step-by-Step Turn Summary (and Flowchart) – to be honest, this should probably have been in the first book.
Separating your DM and Player Role – more ways to keep yourself honest when dealing with spoilers and hidden information.
Getting Started and Overcoming Blocks – it can be so difficult to actually pull the trigger and start an adventure, and sometimes a difficult encounter can derail you. DM Yourselves will give techniques for getting past these problems.
Enemy Combat AI – more tips for handling combat (developments, surprise, tactics etc.) and examples for how to use the AI combat tables from the first book.
Extended NPC Reaction Tables – methods for weaving together the information given in the scenario with tables to flesh out the characters and reactions of NPCs you meet.
How to Read Other Styles of Adventure – DM Yourself was based around the scenario format most often used for modern 5e adventures (numbered maps, boxed location descriptions). What do you do if your adventure doesn’t fit that format?
Group Checks – and other rules to watch out for with low player counts.
Making Mistakes and Happy Little Accidents – and playing it your way.
Experiments with Time and Space
Montage (and other non-linear timescales) – experimental tables for breaking away from always being in linear time and instead using some scenes as montage, skipping travel with highlights, slow-motion etc.
Viewpoint/Framing/Scene Tables (and other film techniques) - experimental tables for breaking away from always being in first person and instead doing some scenes using other viewpoints and cinematic techniques.
Getting Inside the Head of Your Character – sort of like the Immersion Table, but inside your character’s head.
Zoomed-Out Play (how to drop the details but still get the story) – sometimes you want the story but without playing out every scene turn-by-turn. DM Yourselves  will give some tips playing in a more ‘zoomed-out’ way by dropping the detailed combat and using just a few dice rolls to resolve each room.

campaign.story:
The Wizard's Grimoire
A few years ago now, I designed a game called The Wizard's Grimoire. In it, you play an ambitious minor wizard who's come into possession of a grimoire beyond your arts. Can you study and unlock it? What wizardries does it contain? Into what troubles and adventures will your ambitions lead you?
Since then, I've written several more games set in the same world -- The Barbarian's Bloody Quest, The Last Adventure, The Thief & the Necromancer -- and also additional grimoires for the original game. Each offers new characters to play or new wizardries to unlock and master.
I'd like to bring these games to a wider audience. In all, I've already written enough material to publish 7 issues of a zine, so that's what I'm going to do!
Gameplay: the Grimoire
At the heart of the game is the grimoire: a text of many sections and its own set of rules. Each section represents a wizardous advancement you can achieve, a new spell you can learn or act of wizardry you can undertake, but each also has its own rules for unlocking and studying them. Don't read ahead! You can only read the sections you've unlocked and studied.
Most wizards' grimoires also include "safeguards," sections you unlock by improper study. These include magical curses, setbacks, and disasters. Trigger a safeguard and the spellbook may rewrite itself, summon a destructive creature from another world, or even send you reeling 10 minutes back into the past. Keep trying to study it without disarming the safeguard, and it'll keep sending you back!
Your first grimoire is a challenging 1st-level text called "The Signature of Aibesta of the Two Courts." Aibesta of the Two Courts was a powerful wizard of an age some four centuries past. Her grimoire includes the techniques to summon an Impeccable Servant, a powerful familiar and bodyguard, an act of wizardry that Aibesta undertook but never accomplished.
Work your way through the entire grimoire, and not only will you learn powerful new spells, you'll establish your workroom, the foundation of your future seclusium; you'll learn techniques to better subdue and study future grimoires; and you'll accomplish what Aibesta herself couldn't: the summoning of an Impeccable Servant!
Gameplay: You and Your Volunteers
To play The Wizard's Grimoire, you need two volunteers (or three works fine) to play against you. Only you, the wizard player, need to know the rules. You're responsible for knowing your own rules and making your own calls. You're also responsible for telling your volunteers any points of continuity that you want them to know.
In this way, the game upends the normal player-GM relationship. Instead of a GM saying, "hey, I have this game I'd like to run, who's in?" you say, "hey, I'm trying to get my wizard through this spellbook, do you have a minute?"
Each session that you play is an episode in your wizard's study and adventures. They can be as short or as long as you like, you can play as often or rarely as you like, and you can have different volunteers, or the same ones, every time you play.
Gameplay: System & Dice
The Wizard's Grimoire uses a dice pool version of the good old PbtA moves.
You have ratings for your moves based on your qualities -- for instance, your rating to exert yourself subtly to take surreptitious action is equal to your Ambitious + your Cunning, while your rating to exert yourself violently against an enemy is equal to your Bold + your Cunning. Roll that many dice, count the 4s, 5s and 6s as hits, and if you roll no hits, it's a miss. Usually, you get to spend your hits on things you want to happen or questions you want to ask, but you know how it is with moves, they each work a little differently.
Since you both call for your own rolls and interpret their results for yourself, the moves answer to different design concerns than they do in a conventional PbtA game. I think they're pretty interesting, and if you're a PbtA-head like me, I think you will too.
Future Issues (Spoilers!)
 The Dictum of Polume the Farer: An easy and useful 1st-level grimoire, including such spells as creating a scampering lantern and summoning a jarful of plasmic hornets. You can study it alongside Aibesta's Signature for very good results.
 The Barbarian's Bloody Quest: Can you find and slay the wizard who butchered and subjugated your family? Includes "The Book of Doomed Wizards." 
 The Three Scrolls of Jorvelte Wild-Crowned: A 2nd-level grimoire, including the wizardous techniques to enchant magical items, including a useful and dangerous staff of glimmering menace.
 The Last Adventure: In your youth, you were a warrior and a hero. Now you're dead, but no one brought you the sup of oblivion. Take up the memory of your old sword, the memory of your old helmet, and make your last adventure here in the land of death. Includes "In the Land of Death" and "Answering the Calling Voice." 
 The Red Tome of Salabrusto the Wise: A 2nd-level grimoire, including an almanac of alien worlds and planes, and wizardous techniques both to travel to them and summon entities from them.
 The Thief & the Necromancer: You're friends, a gifted necromancer and a thief and street performer. You've both escaped bad situations and you've thrown in together to take on the world. Includes "Goerne, a Ghostly Tutor." 
Attention: Patrons
If you support lumpley games on Patreon, you'll already get the digital version of The Wizard's Grimoire as a patron reward. Don't sign up for it here!
If you'd like a copy in print, though, this is the best way to get one.
Reduced Price Level & Community Copies
Times are tight!
If you want to support the project but the full price is a stretch, or if you're curious about the game but can't justify paying full price sight unseen, we've been there! Please feel free to join in at the reduced price level.
When we publish, we'll also make a number of free, community-supported copies available, no questions asked. If you can't join in now, please reshare the project and pick up a community copy when they come out.
Thanks!

campaign.story:
What is this?
Against the Dark Conspiracy is a tabletop roleplaying game for 2–5 players and 1 gamemaster (GM) about capable professionals confronting a shadowy supernatural Conspiracy before it comes for them or those they care about.
Against the Dark Conspiracy is a rules light supernatural thriller game with mechanics built out from Cthulhu Dark (by Graham Walmsley). For a free introduction to an earlier iteration of some of the game's core mechanics check out my game Alien Dark. 
Players take the role of people who previously made their living in Europe's overlapping  crime and espionage communities. That's how they discovered the Conspiracy behind the skein of what passed for their normal lives. The die was cast; they can never unknow what they have discovered; never go back to what they were before. 
Doing dubious and dangerous things for their country &/or personal gain has left them with few ties to family or friends, making the ones they have left all the more important. That's why they have to make a stand and take the Conspiracy down one corrupt piece at a time, before it catches up with them and anyone who still cares about them. 
You can see the first of a 3 session series using the current playtest packet of Against the Dark Conspiracy, here.  If the players are happy for them to be released then Session 2 will be available during the campaign and Session 3 just after it finishes - find me on twitter @AlunRees14 for updates. I'm running a one-shot of Against the Dark Conspiracy for Gauntlet Community Open Gaming on 27 February.
You can also find a 'design diary' I wrote for The Gauntlet RPG Community blog, here.
                                  The Zine
The Zine will be a 40-page, 8.5" x 5.5" PDF graced with greyscale cover art by Kasha Mika.
If, together, we successfully reach stretch goals then the page count will increase to match the growth of content and art options.
The Zine will offer tables to help the GM and players define the nature of the operations they will embark upon, as well as the powers and weaknesses of their supernatural foes. The GM will choose from those lists to create the kinds of supernatural threat they and their players want to see in their game.  The default antagonists are vampires, but stretch goals will expand the options.
Backers at the Digital Enhancement ... level, and above, will also receive a code enabling them to get an at cost physical copy of the Zine shipped direct to them via DrivethruRPG.  
 The Game 
In a setting inspired by Night's Black Agents (by Ken Hite), Against the Dark Conspiracy builds player characters based on what they used to do for an intelligence or criminal organisation along with their particular area of brilliance. This creates characters with a specific skill-set and expertise and ensures everyone gets their time in the spotlight. It explores their motivation for standing up to the Conspiracy and their relationships with other characters and the non-player character they need to protect from their foes. This gives the players plenty of hooks on which to hang their role-play.
If they lack a necessary expertise or need fictional positioning for some action, they can flash back to call on a contact for help, developing a network of NPCs they can (usually) rely on, but who may in turn attract the attention of the Conspiracy. Having your network driven underground is a real pain!  
Gameplay is designed around a cycle that sees characters:
 Gather Intel: to get answers to specific questions about their current operation but also increase their broader understanding of the Conspiracy and its activities. 
 Spend Intel: to take some narrative control by defining the location, target, likely opposition and even the specific obstacles they'll face in an upcoming operation, or to force the GM to reveal the Powers or Weaknesses of their supernatural foes. 
Cycle of Play
Deciding how to spend Intel gives players some control over how quickly the level of threat increases, from mundane criminal or para-military pawns of the Conspiracy to supernatural foes of increasing potency. They decide if they want to know more about the supernatural or about the immediate obstacles they'll face in their operations. How much do they want to know for certain before they try to put a stake in the very heart of the Conspiracy?
All the while, there's a risk that the Conspiracy is finding out as much about the characters as they discover about it.  Clumsy and noisy failures move the Conspiracy from being just suspicious, through alarmed, to the point where they come after the team wherever they are. Alternatively, the Conspiracy may go after their network of contacts or the person they want (and need) to protect.
During play characters will, inevitably, accumulate Stress and when their Stress track fills the player narrates how they leave the game. Heroically? Or will it be to become a pawn? Character generation takes only a few minutes so characters can be replaced on the fly if a player gets careless and fails to seek relief from the horror. Whether it's being drunk on the job, or indulging some other vice, or seeking solace from a friend or mentor in moments between the action, there's always a price to pay, but it can keep you going. Sometimes that price is paid by the character or the person that matters most to them, sometimes by the operation, and sometimes by another player character.
For a free introduction to an early iteration of some of the game's core mechanics look at Alien Dark.
You can see the first of a 3 session series using the current playtest packet of Against the Dark Conspiracy run for the Gauntlet RPG Community, here.  If the players are happy for them to be released then Session 2 will be available during the campaign and Session 3 before it finishes - find me on twitter @AlunRees14 for updates.  I'm also running a one-shot of Against the Dark Conspiracy for Gauntlet Community Open Gaming on 27 February.
You can also find a 'design diary' I wrote for The Gauntlet RPG Community blog, here.
                                    Stretch Goals
£1200 - a new Conspiracy
When we hit £1200, I'll include details of a Demononic Conspiracy along with new Powers, Weaknesses, and supernatural proxies for them to deploy against the player characters.

 £1400 - another new Conspiracy 
When we hit £1400, I'll include a Fae Conspiracy along with new Powers, Weaknesses, and supernatural proxies for them to deploy against the player characters.

£1600 - Operation Underground
When we hit £1600, I'll include a detailed example of how to build an Operation from the tables provided and player responses, with the added benefit of giving a GM an operation they can throw at players as soon as they open the Zine.

£1900 - more Art!
When we hit £1900, the art budget will increase.

£2200 - Expanded GM Guidance
When we hit £2200, I'll include additional guidance for the GM that the current page count doesn't allow.

£2500 - Player character sorcery ...
When we hit £2500, I'll add the Librarian as a playable option. With their dark desire for the blasphemous unknown they will come with additional rules to use sorcery against the Conspiracy.  There's a risk, of course ... dabbling in the black arts is never simple ... or safe ...

£3000+ ... that's a Conspiracy secret ...
                              The Designer
I'm Alun Rees and this is my first kickstarter.  
I usually facilitate 2 sessions a week as part of the Gauntlet RPG Community, and one for my 'home-online-group'.
What drives me to design games is a desire to find the least intrusive mechanics to hit the beats and tone of genres that attract me, as I hope you can see in my previous games, here.  
You can hear some of the thoughts that led to the seek relief from the horror move in this game, here, and why my game of the year for 2020 was Fate of Cthulhu, here.

updates.update_userinfo: It's been about a month so ...
updates.update_content:
... time for a very brief update.
I'm focused on getting the draft that the editor has had a go at knocked about a bit while Kasha has been working on the look of the cover ...

Kasha has mocked up the cover art and is working on turning the outline into the real thing while the text is now pretty complete and I've done a rough layout.  Everything still looks set for completion in June as planned.
The surprise is that the pdf is coming in at 100+ pages rather than the 40-60 I'd envisaged!
I hope that's not going to be a cause for complaint, folks ... you thought you were getting a 40 page zine and suddenly it's a book bursting past 100 pages.  My fingers are crossed this is OK with you ...

I started a series of 4 sessions on Sunday to check out the Demonic Conspiracy and it felt good.  I've never had a vampire 'summon & command insects' to make life difficult for the characters, yet it seemed very logical for the cult leader operating as a circus ringmaster to do so when the team crashed his ritual and bust his 'wards and bindings'.  Who doesn't want to thwart some cultist-clowns tryinig to sacrifice a diplomat?
What didn't go well was the recent change to the bit of Operation construction called 'Motive'.  So, I've finally admitted that a set of generic 'motives' for each of the three flavours of Conspiracy just don't provide enough of a hook for players. Being told that the motive is related to 'a reward of someone/something for someone/something' doesn;t scaffold players to frame sharp Investigative scenes.

The tabes with which players &/or GM can generate Operations are coming along nicely. 
There are now 12 Leads rather then the original 6 I've been playtesting with.
Meanwhile, the choice of Operational Targets has risen from 24 to 72.  Each of those can present a situation with more or less bystander activity/risk to provide 144 different starting set-ups for Investigative scenes to flesh out.

As planned I used the The Harker Intrusion from Pelgrane to test how easy it was to hack a published set of missions into Against the Dark Conspiracy.  The players had completed the initial stages of character generation in advance and 25 minutes was taken up with some breaks every hours or so. We ended up playing for about 3.5 hours.  
You can find the session here ... https://youtu.be/KtA_9B4YWhk, BUT SPOILER ALERT if you haven't played the Harker Intrusion.  I'll give away no detail in this uodate, though.

Well that was incredible! 
In that last couple of hours you powered the project through the Fae Conspiracy stretch goal, so these servant of the Old Gods of the Earth will be part of the final zine.  Those forgotten gods and spirits who arose with the dawn of humankind are bitter and want revenge. Will you be able to stop them exacting tribute from a human race that left them behind and turned them into the subjects of stories with which to frighten children.  They want to taste the fear of all humans ... that may go some way to repaying the debt they believe they are owed.

campaign.story:
External Containment Bureau is a game of paranormal investigation and bureaucracy using a lightweight, hackable version of the Forged in the Dark design framework. You play as trained agents of the External Containment Bureau, an organization tasked with the study, identification, and containment of paranormal phenomena. The Bureau authorizes agents to make use of these phenomena to give yourself incredible powers (so long as the proper forms are in order). But take care: using paranormal energies inches you ever closer to joining the ranks of the paranormal yourself. Will you transcend humanity in the line of duty? Play to find out.
If you enjoy media like Control, Fringe, The Magnus Archives, Men in Black, SCP Foundation, or X-Files... you'll love External Containment Bureau!

Check out the current state of the game in this actual play(test) session on our YouTube channel:
 Like what you see here? Eager to try it out for yourself? Click the button below to generate your own copy of a FREE Quickstart Keeper document powered by Google Sheets. Inside, you'll find an overview of gameplay and basic rules, pregenerated character sheets for up to four agent players, and a GM tab that tracks all important agent information and provides a sample mission to introduce you to the paranormal nature of the External Collections Bureau.
Click the button above to access the Quickstart Keeper!
The Game
The Bureau
The work of the External Containment Bureau (ECB) is founded on three principles:
 Identify: Both in the office and in the field, it's the responsibility of agents to study and identify paranormal phenomena. The Bureau's various departments work together to add to the Bureau's knowledge base.
 Obscure: Paranormal phenomena and the mundane world don't easily mix. For the sake of both the public good and the health of paranormal sentience, it is the prerogative of every agent to obscure the true nature of paranormal phenomena.
 Contain: The Bureau's purpose is to preserve a healthy balance between paranormal phenomena and the mundane world. Agents are expected to find safe havens for the paranormal in their local environments or, failing that, provide adequate accommodations at Bureau HQ.
While creating your agent, one of the major considerations is which department you work in at the Bureau. You'll transfer departments throughout your time with the Bureau, learning new skills and making use of specialized gear in each:
External Containment Bureau Departments: Administration, Field Operations, Human Relations, Records, Research + Development, and Sanitation.
Gameplay
External Containment Bureau makes use of a streamlined version of the Forged in the Dark design framework. Cut to the drama, take action, deal with the consequences, and balance your life between Field and Bureau phases of play.
Two of the core mechanics in External Containment Bureau are redaction and resonance. Don't like the consequences of your actions? Redact them from the record and roll the dice to see how much resonance you gain with the paranormal energies around you as a result. Gaining resonance gives you incredible paranormal powers but beware: eventually you might resonate so much with these energies that you transcend humanity. At that point, the work of the Bureau is beyond your consideration.
Trained agents of the Bureau
Redacted Material License
From the very beginning, External Containment Bureau has been designed with easy hacking in mind. If you want to create your own games that make use of ECB's streamlined mechanics, paranormal themes, or bureaucratic processes, the game includes a free license to help you out. We're still working out the details, but all games inspired by ECB will be known as REDACTED MATERIAL.
Redacted Material License Logo
The Campaign
 We're keeping our backer levels nice and simple for this campaign:
 Intern ($1+): Back at this level and receive our thanks for helping the External Containment Bureau succeed in its mission!
 Digital Agent ($10): Back at this level to receive a digital PDF copy of External Containment Bureau. This PDF is print-ready so you can print your own copy at a local print shop.
 Print Agent ($20): Back at this level for a print-ready digital PDF and a printed zine of External Containment Bureau. 
 Manager ($50): Receive a print-ready digital PDF and five copies of the printed zine. You'll have enough for an entire team of agents!
 Director ($100): Receive a print-ready PDF and a printed zine of External Containment Bureau. Plus, a member of the design team will run a virtual one-shot session for you and up to four friends. Please note: this session must be scheduled within three months of the game's fulfillment date (estimated August 2021) and we reserve the right to turn down anyone we don't want to run a game for. 
We plan to have all of these products ready for fulfillment by August 2021. See the Risks and Challenges section below for additional info.
Three paranormal entities already encountered and contained by the work of the Bureau.
Stretch Goals
We've got some very basic stretch goals planned to keep this project exciting and achievable:
UNLOCKED! $5000: New Cover! We'll commission Julianne Griepp (www.juliannegriepp.com) to create a gorgeous piece of art to replace the standard cover seen at the top of this page.
UNLOCKED! Every $1000 More: New Art! After our first stretch goal, every additional $1000 in funding will give us the budget to commission a black and white illustration to appear on the game's pages. If we raise $10,000, we'll have paid for a full slate of art from Julianne. Everything beyond that will continue to raise the shares of each core collaborator.
Julianne's work as seen on the cover of Alice is Missing, an RPG by Spenser Starke.
Fulfillment
Just like with last year's Zine Quest game, The Mythic Gazetteer is handling fulfillment of physical copies of the zine in-house. Digital copies will be fulfilled via DriveThruRPG or Itch.io, whichever you prefer as a backer. 
DriveThruRPG is phasing out their saddle-stitched Print on Demand option so at the moment, this Kickstarter is the only way to get a print copy of the game. Whether you back at the physical level or you get a print-ready PDF... plan accordingly!
Digital fulfillment through DriveThruRPG and itch.io!
IMPORTANT NOTE: We are only able to offer print fulfillment to US and Canadian backers. If you're outside those countries, the digital agent backer level includes a print-ready file so you can create a physical copy at your local print shop. Local printing costs are usually similar to or cheaper than shipping rates for a zine project.
Print fulfillment is available in the US and Canada only
The Team
Our small team is following the co-op model for this project: we all have our roles, but we all share creative control and profit for the project equally. Here's some quick info about each of us, what we've worked on, and where to find us.
 Lexi Antoku (Editing) is a professional Oxford comma advocate and casual cat advocate. They respect English in the same way one might respect hot stoves or wires with frayed insulation.
 Eric Brunsell (Writing) is a professor and game designer based in the US Midwest. You can follow him at adrenalinerpg.itch.io to see what he is up to.
 Michael Elliott (Writing) Michael is a writer and game designer based in the Pacific Northwest. He’s made paranormal games like Area Zero One and Spooky Action at a Distance, and Forged in the Dark games like Neon Black and A Torch in the Dark. You can find him on twitter @KindelingBoy, sohkrates.itch.io, and patreon.com/notwriting.
 Justin Ford (Art Direction, Layout) is a microscopist and game designer based in the Pacific Northwest. Follow him on twitter @Mothlands or at Moth-Lands.itch.io for updates on future [Redacted Material] and other games.
 Eli Kurtz (Production, Layout) is a game designer, cartographer and podcaster in the US Midwest. He's written games like The Summer Greening, Fireside Fables, and his current project, Errant Deeds: Tall Tales in the Blackwood. You can follow Eli on Twitter @ZapDynamic or at his website, MythicGazetteer.com.
Spotlights
Zine Quest 3 is full of cool projects from other RPG designers. Here are a few of our favorites:
 Beakwood Bay is a Brindlewood Bay hack of adventurous mallards and the tales these ducks tell by Jackson Adams. 
 Bloodstained Hands, a solo Rooted in Trophy TTRPG about forgiveness by Vlad Temper.
 The Company: Conflict Resolution Guidelines is a sourcebook and supplement written by many contributors for The Company: Corporate Survival Horror RPG.
 The Concealment Society is a solo journaling game about managing and hiding the weirdness in this world by Doug Levandowski.
 Crescent Moon is an adventure RPG about brave children and their dreams, shadows, and discoveries by ema acosta.
 Hibernation Games is a collection of 5 journaling RPGs for solo play by Lucian Kahn, Jeeyon Shim, Anna Anthropy, Viditya Voleti, and Will Jobst.
 High Speed, Low Drag is a solo journaling TTRPG that follows the career of an elite soldier on and off the battlefield by Tom Mecredy.
 Hope is Not a Plan is a a solo journaling RPG about the existential dread of professional project management by Steve Wright.
 The Last Will and Testament of Gideon Blythe is a solo roleplaying game about family legend, lineage, and the burden of destiny by Jeeyon Shim.
 Lichcraft is an RPG zine about trans people waiting so long for healthcare that they decide to become liches. Written by Laurie O'Connel.
 Neon Gutters is a cyberpunk RPG set in a retro-futuristic Hong Kong, rooted in the mechanics of Trophy RPG. Written by Mason Wong.
 Noctis Labyrinth is a no-prep adventure for World of Dungeons by Duamn Figueroa Rossal.
 Paranormal, Inc. is a GM-less roleplaying game about struggling paranormal investigators.
 Stealing the Throne is an RPG about a heist to steal a thousand year-old mech by Nick Bate.
 Thursday, a tabletop role playing game of time loops, drama, and learning from your mistakes by Eli Seitz.
Check them out and lend your support to them if you can!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The Mythic Gazetteer has two successful Kickstarter campaigns under its belt, both delivered complete and on time. We're also Superbackers, so we've been able to study the triumphs and trials of dozens of Kickstarters. We're bringing that experience to bear in this project.

This is the second time we'll fulfill a project in-house. It's a manageably small project but unforeseen snags are bound to occur. We're working with local shops to provide printing and binding services. These costs are unlikely to change during our project timeline but technical issues may arise.

Our policy is always threefold: achievable goals, open communication, and honest work. We're compensating the folks involved generously. We'll be prompt in communicating all milestones and setbacks. And lastly, we've structured a project we're confident we can achieve.

The Mythic Gazetteer stands in solidarity with the workers of Kickstarter United, organizing with OPEIU Local 153. We believe in their collective power and we follow their lead. If that belief ever comes into conflict with our business here on Kickstarter: we stand with the workers.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter
campaign.env:
Environmental commitments
Visit our Environmental Resources Center to learn how Kickstarter encourages sustainable practices.
Long-lasting design
Zines aren't intended to last a long time, but the digital PDF we're including as a backer reward will last as long as there's electricity.
Reusability and recyclability
Zines aren't intended to last a long time but they're very easy to recycle! This zine in particular will be made of ink, paper, and staples. We'd love it if you recycle your copy when the time comes. And in the meantime... don't hesitate to share your copy around! That's in keeping with the zine way of life too.
Sustainable materials
If possible, we'll print this game on recycled paper. And even if we can't do that, printing a zine has a much lower impact on the environment than, say, mass-producing sets of dice.
Sustainable Distribution
Zines will be printed at local shops and mailed using the existing infrastructure of the US Postal Service. We're only printing enough copies to fulfill the Kickstarter and have a few left over in case anything gets damaged in the mail.

campaign.story:
Dying Hard on Hardlight Station is a new module for the Mothership Sci-Fi Horror RPG. It’s both an open-ended adventure and plug-and-play setting; envisioned as a cyberpunk Xmas mashup of Die Hard and Alien Resurrection. In the adventure, your team of grizzled PCs will be torn between saving friends locked in the Medtech facility or crawling to freedom in the vents of the corporate-controlled Hardlight Station; all while avoiding capture by the brutal Blackshield Mercenary Company. Unbeknownst to all, however, Blackshield’s invasion has caused the containment protocols at the Healthtek facility to malfunction. Now, in the bowels of the station, something horrible has awoken, and, after a long, torturous sleep, they hunger to feed.
Written by D. Kenny with layout by Eric K. Hill & art by Vil, we've designed Hardlight Station for flexible play. It works as a one-shot, mini-series, or as a part of your ongoing Mothership (or any other Sci-Fi RPG) campaign. It’s filled with unique locations, scheming NPCs, and terrifying horrors on the hunt. A night on Hardlight Station is one you won’t soon forget.

Dying Hard on Hardlight Station takes inspiration from two of the greatest sci-fi horror and action franchises of all time and jams them into a compact, highly gameable surface for your enjoyment. Every page of the station is packed with efficient, evocative details big on imagination and light on overlong prose to make the book as table-ready as possible.

Tons of sci-fi mayhem and haunting horrors await in the pages of Dying Hard on Hardlight Station, including:
 Three or more fully mapped station locations - Loaded with loot tables, adventure hooks, custom encounters, and interesting NPCs.
   Three Original Factions - The Blackshield Mercenary Company, Station Administration Nakatomi Solutions Inc, and the ravening Alien Hybrids. Each vying to come out on top in the battle for the station.
   The Hardlight Station Directory - a guidebook filled with shops, entertainments, NPCs and jobs for your crew... should anyone survive the initial adventure.
   Custom art and professional design - Bringing it all to life in glorious red, black, and white.
  Plus a whole lot more!
We've worked hard to make this the most gameable, tightly written, evocatively illustrated, and designed module it can be, and we are very excited to get it into your hands and onto tables around the globe.
Dying Hard on Hardlight Station is designed to be played using the rules for Mothership, the ENnie award-winning (Best Game, Gen Con 2019) sci-fi horror roleplaying game. Both the Mothership system and this module pride themselves on offering easy-to-run rules while keeping the stakes high. You can find the full rules for Mothership in the Player's Survival Guide which is Pay What You Want on DriveThruRPG. That said, if you already have a game-system of choice, this module is built to easily adapt to any TTRPG system you may prefer.

Dying Hard on Hardlight Station is written and produced by a top-notch team:
Written by D. Kenny (Nirvana on Fire).
Layout and Design by Eric K. Hill (Nirvana on Fire, The Third Sector, and Dinoplex: Cataclysm). 
Art by Vil (Dissident Whispers, Horrible Wounds, and A Fistful of Creeps).
Editing by Jarrett Crader of the Moonrat Conspiracy (Mothership Player's Survival Guide, The Ultraviolet Grasslands, Troika!, and many more).  


Dying Hard on Hardlight Station is on its second draft and is currently being polished through supplemental playtesting. We've completed initial layouts and commissioned our first round of illustration.  We're on track to fulfill before our August estimate which has a built-in cushion for any complications that may arise. With that in mind, here is our timeline:
February 2021 - Dying Hard on Hardlight Station Kickstarter.
March 2021 - Writing, playtesting, editing complete.
April 2021 - All art submitted, layout and text finalized. Send to printers. 
May 2021 - Review proofs and make any needed edits.
June 2021 - Print run ordered, stretch goals completed.
July 2021 - Obtain information necessary for fulfillment.
August 2021 - Begin fulfillment. 
Shipping Etc.
Were working with reliable partners to ensure your order arrives on time and in good shape. 
 Exalted Funeral will fulfill physical orders to the USA and the Rest of the World.
