updates.update_userinfo: The Horror on Tau Sigma 7... is Here!
updates.update_content: Hi everyone, here is the progress report for May and we’ve got plenty to share from behind the scenes here at Hardlight Station. Eric has snapped the gantries into place and ordered the last of the reinforced tritanium panels which are now inbound from Io. Ahem… or, for the lay spacefarer what I mean to say is: the primary layout of Dying Hard on Hardlight Station is complete and we’ve sent it off to the wondrous Vil for a few more of his killer art pieces. Once those are in, it’s off to the printers for our proofs and preparing the print order.

updates.update_userinfo: May Update - It's a Big One!
updates.update_content: We’re busy at work tuning Hardlight Station’s reactor core for you all and I’m happy to announce that we’re right on schedule. Primary editing with Jarrett Crader is complete and we’ve turned over the manuscript to Eric to work his layout magic. Meanwhile, Vil, our man with the paintbrush, is hard at work drafting map concepts for the station - tinkering away to find the perfect balance between badass art and maximum playability. In the writing department, work on the main zine is complete and I am now free to go wild on the final stretch goal: the Art and Story Zine. I’ve got a hundred ideas for it; the real task is going to be selecting only the preciousest of morsels to pack into its ink battered pages.

This is it; the pledge manager is open and our pre-order page is live! All you wonderful space rapscallions can now enter the details you’ll need to ensure you get what’s coming to you. We’ve had several requests and questions about pre-orders and add-ons and yes, everything from the Kickstarter campaign is available there, all add-ons including t-shirts, patches, and extra copies of all three (!) zines both pdf and physical. I posted an FAQ in update 12 for you all but if you have any questions feel free to shoot me a message and I'll help you out as quick as I'm able.

Hi rocketeers, we announced earlier this week that the invites for the Pledge Manager would be going out today. As you may have noticed, they have yet to materialize. We've spent the week working the kinks out of the shipping tables in our pledge manager and in the process found some complexities in getting everything operating smoothly . The issue we're working on is ensuring the various rewards and combinations we've unlocked are able to ship at the lowest possible prices to all of you around the world. Rather than rush launching the store, we've decided to delay one week to ensure things go smoothly when we do open the blast doors. In the meantime, I thank you all for your patience while we purge the last of these pesky neutrinos from the reactor core.

updates.update_userinfo: Purging the Fuel Lines before Take Off
updates.update_content: Fwoooooshhh! That’s the sound of the Emails shooting out from all ports on the Pledge Manager Mothership zooming your way with invites to our post-campaign pledge manager page. Our expected launch is this coming week with the bulk of the invites going out Thursday. When your email arrives you’ll be able to access the Pledge Manager to enter your shipping address, get your rewards, sign up for any add-ons you might like, and pay your shipping costs, all in preparation for the big delivery coming this summer.

updates.update_userinfo: “[This is] It, Man. Game [On], Man. Game [On]!”
updates.update_content:
Docking achieved. Welcome to Hardlight Station, everybody!
Here’s a phrase I’ve been repeating for the last two weeks: “What a wild ride!” And, oh boy is that true. With the help of our 1,365 backers, we raised $26,723 CAD and unlocked 9 stretch goals along the way. Not bad for 14 days.
I would be remiss if I didn’t take this opportunity to thank everyone who made this possible. First of all, I have to thank all of you. Without the support of the many Mothership fans and Zine curious questers out there, this rocket would never have made it out of Earth’s atmosphere. So thank you, very much, one and all. Secondly, I also extend my deepest gratitude to the “stellar” (that will never be more appropriate than it is in this context [because space!]) team who made the engines of this old jalopy burn hotter than the core of the sun. for his expertise in both layout and project management behind the scenes. for art that became instantly inseparable from the aesthetic of the project as a whole. And lastly, a pair of thanks in advance. First to of the Moonrat Conspiracy for applying his expertise to ensure the text absolutely hums with maximum efficiency. And secondly to , a Mothership pamphlet adventure pioneer, for signing on to write our stretch goal prequel adventure.

It’s the final countdown! The clock is nigh to midnight and there is a creaking and a rumbling in the corridors. The party rages on little knowing the eve of horror upon us all…
Dramatic perhaps but this has been one hell of a ride with even more to come. Specifically, now that we’re in our final 48 hours I've got a special Christmas remembrance to share with you.

campaign.story:
Explore an abandoned temple adrift in the middle of Bermuda Triangle-like nebula. Search for the source of an interdiction field that rips ships traveling through the sector out of FTL Jumpspace. Discover the secrets of the ancient structure once devoted to the worship of an extraterrestrial entity, betrayed and imprisoned by the alien species that once revered it.
What We Give to Alien Gods is an existential, survival-style exploration adventure compatible with the Mothership sci-fi horror RPG by Tuesday Knight Games. Alien Gods will be an 8.5" x 5.5" 32-page, staple-bound zine that includes:
Work in progress. Art and layout not final.
Beautiful cover art by Chris Cold 
An exciting dungeon-crawl that can be run as a standalone module or inserted into part of an ongoing campaign
Roleplaying opportunities to explore character growth and the meaning of their player characters' existence 
Editorial Notes and Warden Tips with fun facts, explanations on some of the tools used in the module, and suggestions on how to make the adventure come alive
Art, Stats, and Descriptions of the host of the extraterrestrial entities that players may encounter in the module
Maps and Illustrations, including Warden Aids and Player Handouts
Lots and lots and lots of tables for generating encounters, and more!
If we manage to pass our initial funding goal with your help, we have a few exciting Stretch Goals that will be added on to your existing pledges (depending on the level selected).
Like any Kickstarter, there are some risks with a project of this scale. What We Give To Alien Gods is written by a small-press, indie publishing house Lone Archivist Press which consists of one person, me, Lone Archivist. However, since I'm coming off of the end of a successful previous Kickstarter, PRIMEVAL_, I can confidently say that, if funded, I'll be able to deliver a quality product in a timely manner.
That said, stuff still happens. So here is a brief list of some generous milestones that I have mapped out for the coming months to give backers a general idea of progress and the internal deadlines being set to ensure that we can start shipping out the rewards on-time. Or as close to it as possible.
February 2021 - Alien Gods Kickstarter
April 2021 - Final draft completed and any additional edits.
April-May 2021 - Sent to Mixam for Review Proofs; Make any needed print/graphic edits
July 2021 - Complete work on stretch goals if met; Obtain final fulfillment info
August 2021 - Begin fulfillment
Digital Fulfillment will be completed through Itch.io.
Physical Fulfillment Will be completed in-house. Due to changes with shipping platforms, rates, and legal requirements over the last few months, Shipping will no longer be included in the backing pledges. Shipping fees will be added on during the pledge management and may vary depending on your location.
Because of this, I'm trying to keep all stretch goals something that can fit into an envelope along with the zine so that I can keep shipping costs down and continue to keep shipping available worldwide.
Estimated Shipping Costs (in USD)
US +$5
Canada +$10
Worldwide +$13
UK +$11

It's like a 'Legend of Zelda' puzzle dungeon, but instead of Link, you play as a group of grubby grave robbers. Also, there's way more eyeball stuff. 👁
 10 room dungeon crawl where each location has its own mysteries to poke and experiment with
 Cohesive puzzles that build on each other
Lets players to discover their own solutions in true OSR fashion
 Magic items and equipment that change how the players interact with their environment and previously explored areas
Use as a 4-6 hour one-shot or the start to a planar hopping campaign for wherever you'd like to go 
zine cover mockup
sample spread
Puzzle Dungeon: The Seers Sanctum can be used with any tabletop adventure game rule set. It includes monster statistics in the format popularized by the Old School Revival, but you can easily swap them out for monsters in your system of choice. B/X OSE, Knave, Maze Rats, 5e... w/e np.
phone mockup
Bryce Lynch of tenfootpole, writes:
 "Interactivity is very high, rivaling the best of adventure in that area." 
"Far too often 'Puzzle Dungeons' and interactivity is [a] simple something like a riddle or some other forced concept that is divorced, mostly, from the theming of the adventure... This dungeon doesn’t do that. It’s less puzzle, in that definition and more 'the dude who built this house was really into eyeballs.' The dude, in [this] case, being the eyeball religious cult that used to live here."
For this Zine Quest, I want to bring my first published adventure to physical print. Its design is something that print on demand printers can't really deliver, so I'm bulk printing with Mixam. It turns out, this professional printer has the right combination of options to bring this vision to life.
 Professionally printed 8.5x5.5 inch, 22 page, staple bound book on beautiful, high quality paper.

campaign.story:
"One sits down on a desert sand dune, sees nothing, hears nothing. Yet through the silence something throbs, and gleams...”
― Antoine de Saint-Exupéry
Desert Moon of Karth is a space western sandbox adventure zine for the Mothership Sci-Fi Horror RPG. 
Karth is a tiny mesa studded moon on the galaxy's edge. The only way down is an antique space elevator to the lawless boomtown of Larstown; a place surrounded by even greater danger and strangeness in the wastes beyond. Survival or salvation is not guaranteed, partner.
Harvest ossified coral corpses to live forever. Become an involuntary organ donor. Dodge ancient orbital defenses. Explore sand blown ruins. Hunt the fearsome sandsquid. Ride camels through the dunes. Drink whisky until you’ve forgotten your own name.
Karth's inspirations include Dune, Firefly, Alien, John Carter of Mars, Cowboy Bebop, The Dark Tower, spaghetti westerns, and modern adventures like Hot Springs Island, A Pound of Flesh, Ultraviolet Grasslands, and Slumbering Ursine Dunes.
You'll find plenty to use for your other sci-fi RPG of choice like Stars Without Number, Traveler, or Starfinder with a touch of back alley stat surgery.
Mockup of Draft Spread
Desert Moon of Karth is a meaty 52 pages, chock full of evocative illustrations and also includes:
 10 detailed and dangerous locations to explore including a ship graveyard, camel ranch, organic coral caves, and a decadent shattered spire.
 Regional Moon Map and rules for point crawling navigation.
 Detailed colonial Larstown map, rumors, NPC’s, prospective jobs, and fine establishments.
 5 volatile factions for players to interact with including marooned pirates, immortal organ harvesters, tribal park rangers, extinct coral beings, and a colonial boomtown of prospectors.
 Evolving encounters based on the day/night cycle (and it’s sometimes night for a week).
 Tons of 1d10 tables ranging from creepy prayers, to strange technology, to requested organs, to random drugs.
 Rules for sandsquid hunting and a dungeon crawl within one, should you be devoured.
 5 detailed dungeon maps, 8 new creatures, the dark secrets of eternal youth and more! 
Zine Review by the esteemed Tony Vasinda
Writing:
I'm Joel Hines, a National Park ranger, hobby RPG writer, and I bake a real tasty peach pie. After graduating from the University of Puget Sound into a weird world I've GM'd several long term campaigns in a variety of systems and have an abiding love of fantasy, OSR, and pulpy sci-fi. Also, several years back I started saying "Howdy" when I pass people on the trail and now I can't stop.

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
While I believe the scope of this project is eminently manageable there are risks involved. It’s important to note that I am one person and that this is my first Kickstarter and commercial RPG product. However it is not my first time designing RPG content, working on a complex written project with a long term timeline, or cooperating closely with a variety of third parties. 

I've purposely streamlined the project to focus on core zine content and not worry about shipping physical stretch goals. I’m also working with several highly capable collaborators with a history of delivering excellent work. Currently the vast majority of written content has already been produced. While I am thankfully healthy and financially stable, in the event that I’m hit by lightning, global pandemic, or otherwise incapacitated in a way that renders me unable to fulfill the project I would have all all existing content released free to backers digitally.

updates.update_content:
Munificent backers,
The sun has been out more, birds are chirping, and Desert Moon of Karth is rolling along towards production.
 I have just completed all edits based on broad developmental feedback from Ian Yusem and Jarret Crader. These took longer than predicted as a big chunk of the month turned out being spent on increased detailing and partial section rewrites as my final draft turned out to be less final than anticipated as good ideas for improvement and suggestions kept coming into being. This was time well spent as it's made the resulting zine smoother, meaner, and a better experience at the table.  I also was able to fit the Bounty Hunt Generators and Dueling Rules Stretch Goal within the body of the zine itself so it'll be easily accessible in play!

Munificent backers,

I wanted to give an early status report this month to update you all on where things are as we start off  as well as sharing some fresh content with you.

campaign.story:
Mask of the Rose is a romantic visual novel about love, mystery, the restructuring of society after profound change, and bats.
In one playthrough of Mask of the Rose you might romance a partner, or help your friends find love; untangle a poisoner's motives, or uncover the fate of poor, drowned Parliament; house some of London's new, not-so-human inhabitants, or help establish the new Feast of the Rose, a festival that will be celebrated in London for decades to come!
By replaying you can explore different storylines and pursue new goals. London’s deeper secrets will only emerge over multiple playthroughs!
The gameplay of Mask of the Rose extends beyond dialogue. You'll open new locations on the map, gather outfits and disguises, work odd jobs and collect resources. Together, this will determine what you can attempt in social situations – and how much you can get away with!
Mask of the Rose will be coming to console platforms as well as PC, Mac and Linux. We’re offering Steam or GOG keys as backer rewards. Mask of the Rose will also be available on Switch, PlayStation 4 and 5, and Xbox One and Series X/S. 
Mask of the Rose is set in Fallen London: a darkly hilarious gothic underworld where death is a temporary inconvenience, the rats talk, and Hell is only a train journey away. 
We’ve been exploring the Fallen London universe over eleven years and five different games (including Fallen London, Sunless Sea, and Sunless Skies). If you’re a newcomer, Mask of the Rose is the perfect jumping-on point. If you’re already a fan, it offers new discoveries and a chance to explore more personal stories, including encounters with favourite characters.
Mask of the Rose begins in 1862, just months after London was stolen by bats and relocated to the Neath: a vast cavern far below the earth. Down here, the sun doesn't shine, and Parliament has sunk into the Thames. Queen Victoria never emerges from her palace. Cats spy on their owners and whisper their secrets abroad. And it's rapidly becoming clear that London isn't going to be returning to the Surface any time soon…

When you create your character in Mask of the Rose, you’ll choose what your life was like before you were caught in London’s fall. Were your family landed gentry? Or did they own a tailor’s shop, or work on the docks? Your choice will determine how you dress, what you know, and where you fit in.
Whatever your origins, the Fall cut you off from your family and resources. Now, you are beginning a new job for none other than Mr Pages, one of London’s mysterious new Masters...

The old laws are suddenly in disarray, and London's citizens must make new lives for themselves.
For your fellow lodger Griz, the Fall is a liberation – the chance to be taken seriously in a position that would have been denied her when she was 'Miss Griselda'.
For your other housemate Archie, the change is terrifying. What is a medical student supposed to believe in when even the laws of death no longer apply?
And when Archie is arrested for murder (even though the victim has since returned to life, and is feeling much better now thanks) you may begin to moonlight in detective work. Can you crack the mystery of London's first homicide since the Fall?
London is rather the worse for wear after being dragged below ground. Not everything survived, nothing is the same, and no one can quite explain what has happened.
In Mask of the Rose you'll be able to visit a number of different locations in the city, including:

Before London fell, Horatia’s was your temporary home. Now it’s the only place in the city that feels familiar – until, that is, one of your own is arrested, and Horatia starts taking in new lodgers – not all of them human.

After surviving the Fall relatively intact, Tentergrounds has become a home to many. Among them is David – Fallen London’s first murder victim – as he tries to understand his own death and return.

Crucial secrets are hidden in your own fragmented memories of London's Fall. But are you brave enough to relive them?

A new literary salon is gathering all the brightest stars in London. The host has amber eyes, a scalding handshake, and a previous address in Hell itself, but he’s an excellent listener.

Once a 40-gun frigate, the HMS Ungulate has been converted into a temporary prison. Unless you can prove his innocence, Archie may be spending a very long time there.
Mask of the Rose is a story about love, in many forms. The choice is yours: will you be a brilliant matchmaker, connecting friends and rivals while remaining unattached yourself? Or are you looking for lasting love? Or shorter assignations? Or perhaps you're open to whatever comes your way?
Every major storyline will be accessible regardless of whether your approach is romantic or platonic – even if the final endings may vary.
Here are a few of the characters you'll meet:

Rachel was halfway through her latest novel when normal, workaday London ceased to exist – and her literary inspiration along with it. But meeting Milton has rekindled her passion for writing. He might be her suitor; he might be her Muse; he might be an actual devil, if you believe in that kind of thing. Her brother David hates him, but Rachel isn’t about to let that stand in her way.

Harjit hasn't lived in London long. But when catastrophe struck, he knew someone would need to organise volunteers, dig out basements, and round up the lost. Besides, he had a missing person of his own to find. For lack of other options, he stepped into a constable's uniform – and into a job that grows daily more unpredictable.
Now he’s had to arrest Archie for murder. The evidence says Archie did it. Harjit’s intuition points the other way – but lately, trusting his intuition has led only to heartbreak.

For a decade, Horatia has taken in lodgers and turned them into family. But since the Fall, supplies are scarce, and her boarders can't afford their rent. So when a man made entirely of clay knocks at the door, offering to pay handsomely for lodgings, she can hardly refuse.

Mr Pages runs the Ministry of Accounting and Recounting, which has embarked on the titanic endeavour of conducting Fallen London’s first census! A lover of the written word, Pages has never struck such a rich vein as London.
It does have a lot of questions for you, however. How do people declare their affectioniments, in this fair city? How lasting are their attachments? Might a Londoner take an interest in a very tall, broad-shouldered, cloaked personage that leans towards the chiropterous, hypothetistically speaking?
Express Yourself through Fashion. In Mask of the Rose you are what you wear. Manage an expanding wardrobe that offers a host of options. Sometimes the right disguise or outfit will get you into a social occasion. Other times, the effect will be more subtle: giving you the confidence to take a reckless action, or provoking the reaction you need from another character.
Explore widely. Experience the city through three seasons – the season of confessions, the season of Yule, and the season of the Feast of the Rose. Each day you’ll read the news, learn of any recent events and opportunities, and then turn to the map to choose your next action. Will you find Rachel and interrogate her about the night of the murder? Comfort Archie in prison? Work at one of several jobs to earn money, or use your resources to unlock a new part of the city?
Collect the stories of Londoners – and especially their affairs of the heart. You begin as a census-taker with a notebook full of questions. The more you learn, the more it fills up – and unlocks new lines of inquiry. For some reason, Mr Pages is especially keen for its census-takers to document the “assignations and besotments” of London’s citizens. Why is it that London’s new Masters are so preoccupied with stories of romance…?
Our digital rewards range from corvid companions to choosing a Fallen London character to feature in Mask of the Rose!  We are delighted to be partnering with Gametee to create and deliver our physical rewards for Mask of the Rose. 
Gametee create items that enhance gaming culture - the finest quality, the most environmentally and socially conscious, and above all, the most beautiful. We have a lot in common with Gametee as independent British businesses, and we admire not just their design aesthetic, but their whole approach - from their remuneration of artists to their environmental policies. When looking for a partner, we were especially impressed with the quality of their products and the creativity of their designs.

Milton’s Parlour, the best (and most unholy) literary salon in London. Sweet honey, heady rose, and the traces of ivy. 
Mr Pages' Den, where scandalous documents urgently await censorship. Parchment, cypress shelving, and just a hint of ink.
A twin pack of gloriously fragranced gaming candles themed to Mask of the Rose. Hand-poured, vegan (100% natural soy wax) and handmade in England. They burn for up to 20 hours and come in keepsake tins.
Crafted using the finest archival quality cardstock, each magnificent city map measures 42cm X 59cm (16.5 X 23.4in) and will help make better sense of life in the Neath. This map captures London as it was at the time of the Fall. Includes a hand-numbered certificate of authenticity commemorating your special investment in the campaign.
For illustration only, map image may differ.
There are many ways to support this campaign. Our community has been essential to making the world of Fallen London what it is today. Get involved however you can!
UPDATE: We've achieved ALL 20 social goals and ALL of the social rewards!
You've simply bowled us over your romantic poetry, personal ads, Victorian origami, Feast of the Rose celebrations, costumed cats and creatively captured Masters!
Check out our Twitter and #MaskoftheRose to see everything shared and submitted so far. Our wonderful Principal QA Specialist continues to collect and showcase your chiropterous felines on this delightful Twitter thread. Pop into our Discord if you haven’t already to chat about the campaign and all things Mask of the Rose.
You've only gone and unlocked every single social reward! Good work everyone!

Achieving five goals unlocked an access code that will give your character in our Fallen London browser game a special Poetic Gift — just click the link to apply it to your account!
Seven goals unlocked a second Fallen London access code, this time for a mysterious Ministerial Gift. You may want to do so before Monday 22nd February as this gift has a special use during the Feast of the Rose, which you can discover by speaking with Lilac. But don’t worry too much if you miss it – the option will be available again next year.
10 Goals unlocked 10% off at Gametee for a limited time and the release of a free selection of Mask of the Rose and Fallen London-universe themed printables. The discount code has now expired but you can still enjoy the printer-friendly downloadables on Gametee’s website! The items can also be accessed via Dropbox if you prefer not to create a Gametee account.
15 goals unlocked a chance to interview one of the characters from Mask of the Rose! We ran a poll and Milton, he of the amber eyes and scalding handshake, won!
Thank you for the many (184!) questions you submitted for Milton. They have all been received, compiled and submitted for consideration. He answered Mr Pages' approved selection in this update.
19 goals unlocked a future encounter in Fallen London with Horatia. Your landlady in Mask of the Rose has a heart of gold and a soft spot for the Neath’s more unusual inhabitants – but how is she doing decades later, in the Fallen London browser game? We will make her current residence open to visitors, creating an opportunity to meet her! This will happen sometime after the campaign, but ahead of the release of Mask of the Rose. In the meantime, Horatia has something for you – may it keep you company until you meet in Fallen London.
All five stretch goals have been unlocked!
Mask of the Rose comes with three initial options to define your protagonist’s background, allowing you to have grown up as a dockside urchin, as a worker in your family’s tailor shop, or among the stifling  pomp and luxury of the aristocracy. Your choice will grant advantages with particular factions in the story, and equip you with some unique clothing options.
This is a fourth origin to select when creating your character: the Housebreaker’s Heir, who has a pickpocket’s deftness, several criminal acquaintances, and a fraught relationship to anyone wearing a badge. Each origin grants advantages with certain factions and some unique clothing items!
 Early in Mask of the Rose, your landlady Horatia takes in new lodgers – some human, some decidedly not. We’ll add one of these lodgers as a new character to Mask of the Rose: a Clay Man, fresh from the living city of Polythreme.
He’ll be one of the game’s secondary characters – not as elaborately woven into the central narrative as the main cast, but an interactive character with his own story to explore. What emotions stir beneath his stony exterior? You’ll be able to get to know him better, and perhaps even learn the secret that brought him to Horatia’s door... 
A fifth potential origin for your protagonist: the Undertaker’s Child! Thanks to your family business, you are acquainted with numberless vicars, solicitors, grave-diggers and hearse-makers. You also know perfectly well how Death is supposed to behave – even if Fallen London persistently defies your expectations.
The deviless Virginia will make an appearance in Mask of the Rose. In the years to come, she will go on to be many things in Fallen London – including its Lord Mayor – but she was around long before the city arrived in the Neath. Her story will give us an opportunity to show what she was up to in a newly-arrived, vulnerable London… 
 A sixth protagonist origin will be added to the game: the Scholar of the Occult! The scholar is a historian of esoteric practices ranging from witchcraft to alchemy, and this background gives you an in with academics and the more disreputable sort of artist, and a gift for noticing disturbing things out of the corner of your eye…
WARNING: while the Neath could broadly be described as very occult indeed, its particular brand of the strange has little to do with alchemy, witchcraft, angelology, or other surface occultisms. A Scholar of the Occult is as likely to be bewildered by London’s new home as anyone else, but perhaps they will be a little more accepting of the eerie and the uncanny.
Our answer to this might be a little unusual. We're doing okay right now, and can fully fund development of Mask of the Rose (though any pledges we receive will reduce the risk and put us in a better position for the future).
Instead, we're doing this to find out whether this is a game you want us to make.  We're excited about Mask of the Rose; we hope you are, too. The funding goal is not how much it will cost to make; it's the amount that would convince us Mask of the Rose will appeal to a large enough audience, so that we can safely commit to making it.
We won't be making Mask of the Rose available in Early Access, so we're also hoping to learn how you feel about different parts of the game, to help guide development. If you have thoughts to share on any part of the game, please let us know in the comments!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Mask of the Rose is in some ways more complex than many visual novels. But it will be smaller and more focused than most of our past games, which can be enormous and – we confess – somewhat baroque.

We're familiar with the technologies we're using to make it, and have already built a vertical slice – a short, fully playable section of the game. We’ve also had a fair amount of experience fulfilling Kickstarters: we’ve run three successful ones, and delivered on all of them.

For these reasons, we're confident in our ability to complete Mask of the Rose. We think the biggest risk is instead that it might take longer than estimated. In particular, we have a tendency to delay our games if part of the design isn't working out as well as we'd hoped – it's more important to us to make good games than to release them quickly. Also, it's very important to us that our team doesn't have to crunch. That means that if some things take longer than we expect, we might have to push back the release (although we’ve included contingency in the schedule to cover a certain amount of this).

If everything goes to schedule, we expect to be ready to release Mask of the Rose towards the end of 2021, but to account for these risks, the date we’re committing to is June 2022.

This blog is by our Director of Narrative, Chris Gardiner
The Fallen London universe is more than ten years old and consists of actual millions of words. Fortunately, the nineteenth century is a bottomless wellspring of improbable stories, bleak horror, and fascinating characters, and even after all the time we’ve spent in Fallen London, there are still huge areas we’ve never touched on.

updates.update_userinfo: Character Positioning in Mask of the Rose
updates.update_content:
This blog is by our Art Director, Paul Arendt. We’ll be back with more staff updates like this one during the development process!
Staging scenes in a visual novel is a little like directing a play;  you have a set, lighting, props and a cast of actors with lines to say and emotional attitudes to accompany them.
However, in Mask of the Rose, the player’s ability to choose means that we often don’t know which character will be appearing when, which makes arranging them artfully on the screen – blocking, in stage parlance – rather difficult.

updates.update_userinfo: Making the Mask of the Rose Campaign Video
updates.update_content:
by Stuart Young, Senior Producer for Mask of the Rose. We'll be back with more staff updates like this one during the development process!
From the moment we decided to create a Kickstarter campaign for Mask of the Rose, we knew we needed a bespoke campaign video. We’d already made an announcement trailer for Mask of The Rose,  but this wasn’t enough for a Kickstarter campaign. The trailer is quite brief, doesn’t show in-game screens, and it’s mostly in-universe; there’s no-one from the team talking about what the project is or why you might consider backing it.

Thank you all for backing our campaign for Mask of the Rose! We are delighted by your support and excited to begin working on the game in earnest. From here on, you can still expect regular updates from us - about once a month.
The concept for Mask of the Rose came about after our community jokingly asked “Masters Dating Sim when” one too many times, and we snapped. That idea sparked a pitch which eventually grew into the game you have generously chosen to back. This is a project that only came about because of our community.

campaign.story:
What is This?
The Tower & The Garden is a 44 page roleplaying game for zine quest about struggling and surviving in a city (The Garden) grown from the refuse of a fortress of opulence and exclusion (The Tower). You’ll play as cyborgs, mech pilots, magic wielders, and rabble rousers pitted against varied factions who are all vying for control over the Garden: demon lords, criminal enterprises, cultists, and a corporate-sponsored fascist state.
The Cover
Setting
Ravenous supernatural beasts roam the streets at night and cruel imperial soldiers march in the light of the day. Infrastructure and utilities are controlled by wealthy corporations based in the Tower, and the promise of admittance is used to exploit the masses who live in the Garden.
No one remembers how the world ended, but it did. Generations ago. The Tower was built before then. Back then it served as a testament to humanity’s innovative engineering capabilities. When all of the cities were destroyed, it remained standing, and was a beacon of hope, offering its strength and shelter to travelers from near and far. But then the doors slammed shut and the refugee camps surrounding it grew and grew. They grew so large that they merged together into a sprawling city now known as The Garden.
Last year, the self-coronated Emperor of the Iron Tower took a portion of their advanced military machine and went on a pointless crusade against a distant demon lord. Corporations have exerted their control and use the remaining military forces to quell uprisings and protect the exposed people of the Garden from demon attacks, while ignoring the basic human needs of the populace. The scene is set for guardians defenders to rise and protect the populace, or at the very least get what’s coming to them.
The Enhanced Character Class
The Rules
The Tower & The Garden is based on a highly modified, somewhat simplified Forged in the Dark SRD. There is no system for reducing stress, thus characters who are pushed to their limits must change, and bear the scars of their experiences.
The Armored player class, illustrated by Galen Pejeau
Stretch Goals
We have some incredible stretch goals!
$2250 - Demon lord descriptions written by Jordan Shiveley! Jordan is well known for his evocative writing for the Dread Singles (@hottestsingles) twitter account, and has written for many games including The Spire, Emberwind, and City of Mist. His upcoming book of fictions, Hot Singles In Your Area, will be published later this year.
$2350 - Monster descriptions written by P.A. Wikoff! P.A. Wikoff is the author of the Tarnished Lands series of novellas, Feylin Lore: Reflections, and the Imprisoned Online LitRPG series. His stories exude humor and darkness.
$3500 - A one-shot actual play stream will be organized and run by Levon Jihanian! Players will be paid and production quality will be sought out!

campaign.story:
They are so proud, as they build, swarming ever higher and further in pursuit of the prize they call "progress"! Up, into the thick clouds of smog their own machines spew over the dissolute, willfully wasteful city. Outward, across orderly farms and ruined forests and stripped earth, long since plundered, the robbery boasted of as innovation. 
But never down, for below the city, the catacombs wait, the bones within of ancestors and older things, the creatures that slip through the shadows between the infrequent torches the fading remnants of the days before electricity, before newspapers and printing presses and steam-powered engines.
And one shadow, ancient and cold, watches for the venal cracks in fragile souls eager to secure their fortunes for the meager price of their own damnation. An ancient mystery, who calls to the weak-willed and to those willing to bargain, beckoning ever deeper into the dark.
Can you hear it? 
Where Mystery Dwells is a darkly whimsical catacomb crawl through a candlelit world of stone and bones beneath a fantastical-industrial city, one where eccentric patrons demand their apprentices shine the heavy, noxious electric arc lamps of progress on ancient mysteries at any cost, and where those mysteries retaliate with obsession and madness.
It features a high-stakes cyclic solo and duet system, partly inspired by Blades in the Dark and The Skeletons, where you play a troupe of apprentices balancing their own survival and sanity against the need to curry favor with their patron. It also has system-agnostic tools for procedurally generating vaguely disturbing catacombs, creating the colorful city, and populating both with a cast of empathetic and engaging characters.
This kickstarter is to fund a printed-and-shipped version, possibly through Mixam or a local printer, but I'm also considering rolling up my sleeves and digging into my stash of FSC-certified coverstock, mixed media, and that really nice copy paper I accidentally bought way too much of to prepare for sudden home schooling. And I have some limited stocks of the really good stuff (think "French Paper Co.") for the "one of a kind" copies.
Note: "hand-embellished" means splashes of watercolor, mixed media, hand-made stamps, and enthusiasm! Only choose the "one of a kind" option if you want a truly limited edition, one of a kind version.
Stretch goals include hiring artists, custom character sheets, more community copies, more of the limited tier options, and (out there) a custom oracle deck.

campaign.story:
Nagara is old, the city is dying, and you are the only one who can ward off the Doom.
City of Flesh is a tarot-based roleplay game where you play one of the Midwives, a person imbued with primordial energy, tasked with staving off the end of the world as you know it. Together with your fellow players and GM, you create the city of Nagara and its unique locations using a tarot deck. Each session your characters inch ever closer to a Doom they’re working tirelessly to prevent, but must inevitably face as the chronicle ends.
The game has the dark horror feeling of a dungeon crawl, while focusing on mechanics that drive in-game drama and push personal stories. You’ll get embroiled in the various wars raging between guilds in the city and try to secure a bit of personal peace, before all your efforts crumble around you. You’ll strive to survive in a city that is literally trying to eat you, and siphon off its power to keep the ones you love safe.
City of Flesh takes inspiration from grimdark fantasy combining it with a feminine aesthetic to create an immersive gore-splattered roleplay experience where you delve into the dreams of a sleeping colossus and tear through fleshy reality to make your own fate.
What You’ll Get

City of Flesh is an A5 sized, 50+ page, soft cover zine. We've paid attention to paper quality and the zine will have a glorious hand-feel. PDFs will be distributed through DriveThruRPG and physical zines will be sent through the Dutch national mail service. 
Shipping is free, we've calculated the costs into our funding goal.
Within the zine is:
A complete grimdark femmecore setting for you and your friends to build upon
A full set of unique tarot-based mechanics to run your game
A guide on how to interpret the cards for your game
An immersive safety mechanic to keep the game safe and fun for everyone at the table
If you'd like additional physical copies of the game add €15 to your pledge for each additional copy. We'll send PDF codes along with the additional copies ordered.
Take a look at the stretch goals we unlocked!
2,500: UNLOCKED - Monster generator 
3,500: UNLOCKED - Encounter generator
5,000: UNLOCKED - All Stretch Goals printed and added to physical pledges
 6,500: UNLOCKED - Proofing
  Welcome to Nagara
Nagara, the City of Flesh, dominates the Plains of Bone. The world is young, the Age of Titans draws to a close, but the city is ancient. Built in the womb of the slain Colossus, Nagara is both rich and powerful—and already past its prime. A Doom approaches Nagara, as the world rebirths itself into a new, more rational form in which there’s place for neither Titans, nor cities built atop their rotting remains. To facilitate this transition, the city’s dreams birthed the Midwives—people imbued with some of the city’s primordial energy who must guide it to whatever comes next.
The Colossus is dead by any measure of human life, and yet she isn’t— she still undulates with primordial creation, heaving and oozing to form a protective shell around Nagara. The magic of the Sovereigns keeps her dormant, as does the life-leeching magic of lesser citizens and their efforts to keep flesh at bay with fire and blade. Entire city blocks still live under overhangs of flesh as a result of the Years of Suffering, with some citizens carving houses into the red tissue.
The need to drive back the Colossus’ flesh becomes more dire as Nagara expands. Sovereign Nemaida offers rewards to explorers who venture in the necrotic parts of the city to slay monsters and burn away the flesh. The Midwives often find themselves called to the danger the endeavor promises, for there is plenty that can go wrong.
How It's Played
Nagara is dying and will be reborn. At the start of the game you map the city by performing a three-card reading for each location in the city. You’ll map seven locations and then place a single card on the Blooded Sanctum, the Doom—the end of your story. Each location represents one session (roughly four hours) of your game, therefore you’ll play seven sessions before the eighth final session where you encounter the city’s Doom.
At the start of every session players pick a location focus—this is the location the game session is crafted around. The GM crafts the plot of the session based around the conflict and threat of the location.
During the game players perform more readings, drawing a tarot card from the deck, to modify the scenes based on how characters act. Readings help facilitate the drama in your character’s life. Depending on how your Reading turns out, you and/or the GM ascribe meaning to the card drawn.
Example of Play
The Midwives are caught in a waking nightmare of terror and blood where an unhinged Relic stalks and murders people in their sleep. Steffie’s character Torga realizes maybe the Relic can be reasoned with, she asks the Relic if they can help it in some way. Liz, the GM, asks Steffie to make a Pacify reading, because Torga is trying to connect with the Relic.
Steffie draws the Five of Swords. 
The Relic explains that it's enraged, not because it can’t fulfill its destiny, but more because it loved Hydrassa deeply and hates seeing her body so defiled.  Torga reveals she knows the sting of unrequited love too and swears to help. Seeing another being who knows its pain, the Relic asks Torga to take action by returning Hydrassa’s body to her burial tomb. 
Nice to meet you!
Steffie de Vaan is a Dutch author and developer of role playing games and short stories. She developed the Legendlore RPG and V5: Fall of London, and has written for many other settings including Vampire the Masquerade, Changeling the Lost, Exalted, and Harlem Unbound. She loves horror, fantasy, sci-fi stories, and their cross genres in any medium; watching short films and tutorials on YouTube; and inclusive feminism.
Elizabeth Chaipraditkul is the owner of Angry Hamster Publishing and her new game Afterlife: Wandering Souls won an Indie Groundbreaker Award for best setting in 2020. She was the lead developer of the Crescent Empire book for 7th Sea by John Wick Presents, and has written for companies such as Onyx Path Publishing, Chaosium, and Modiphius Entertainment. When not in her own imaginary world Liz keeps busy with crafting and walking her dog. You can find out more about her games at angryhamsterpublishing.com and follow her on Twitter @angryhamsterrpg.
We both live in the Netherlands and met during a freelance writing project for the same company. Together we have a Patreon that supports the game design work we produce together and last year we ran a successful Make/100 Kickstarter that raised over $9,000 and was fulfilled by Liz’s company - Angry Hamster Publishing.

campaign.story:
Bucket of Bolts is a game of iconic spaceships and their infamous captains for one player.
She may not look like much kid, but she’s got it where it counts!
The Bebop. Serenity. The Millennium Falcon. 
You can’t have a good space story without an iconic spaceship. Of course, more often than not, the heroes of the story aren’t flying some shiny new cruiser. Those are for the wealthy, the elites—not our lovable scoundrels. No, they fly the bucket of bolts—the outworn, patched-up junker held together with hope, prayers and duct tape.
The eponymous 'bucket of bolts'
These ships weren’t always hunks of junk though—they have long and storied histories, and might even have been respectable vessels at some point. We only ever see a slice of that story though, a single captain and their motley crew. 
This game flips the perspective.  

The Game.
Bucket of Bolts is a hack of Artefact, my game from last year's ZineQuest. Instead of creating a magical item, this time you'll be telling the story of a single spaceship. You’ll create a brand new freighter, fresh off the manufacturing line, and explore its history through each of the people who captain it. Your ship will change as the decades pass - new names, new parts, fresh paint, fresh starts - until your story draws to a close.
You’ll choose your Captains, bringing them to life with names and details, and create stories of their time with your ship using prompts and tables. When you‘re ready to move on, you’ll choose a Fate for your ship. Maybe it’s traded away fairly, but more likely it’s stolen, captured or even wrecked. You might drift for a while as you wait for your next Captain, or the seat might still be warm when a new one takes over. Either way, the galaxy will change around you, and you’ll see it all from the view in the cockpit.
Like the original Artefact, it’s a great way to spend an hour or two; sketching, world-building and storytelling in your own company. It's also a fantastic way to generate really unique ships for tabletop games like Edge of the Empire, Traveller or Scum & Villainy, with rich backstories, fun details and tonnes of personality.

The Zine.
Format 
A little paper prototype of the zine opening.
I'll be using a new format for the physical rewards. Beak zines take an A3 sheet of paper and fold it into an 8-page A6 booklet. This process leaves one side of the paper blank, that people sometimes use to make a poster.
One of the things that's always bugged me about Artefact is how much flicking around the book you need to do as you play the game. I thought—why not use the blank side of a beak zine for all of the game's content; the tables, questions and prompts you’ll need during play. So that’s what I’m doing.
In Bucket of Bolts, you’ll be able to read through all the rules in the booklet and then unfold it into a complete reference for play. Pretty neat huh?
And here it is closing!
Paper
Extract comes in a range of lovely colours.
Of course, I'm still taking every opportunity to make this little zine a deluxe product. I'll be using one of my favourite paper stocks, G.F Smith Extract.
As well as having some seriously impressive environmental credentials (it's made from recycled coffee cups), it's also just a lovely paper that comes in some great colours. I’m partial to Mustard, as you can see in the prototype, but we’ll see when the print samples arrive.

Ink
Copies of ARTEFACT, outside on a sunny day.
As with my previous projects, I’ll be using Risograph to print the book. That means rich, vivid shades with the aesthetic of screen printing, but viable for large-scale print runs. It’s also one of the most sustainable ways to print, with soy-based inks & low energy machines. It’s going to be beautiful!

Illustration
Torben is very excellent at drawing spaceships.
Speaking of beautiful, I'm also commissioning Torben Bökemeyer again to do some awesome illustrations for the game. Spaceships are his bread & butter, and I think his sharp, detailed style is a really good fit for this game. You’ll have seen his key art at the top of the page, and he's already hard at work on the game's cover.

Collector’s Edition
I'm looking forward to an excuse to get wild with paper & ink combos...
I’m also offering a Collector’s Edition of the game, exclusive to the Kickstarter, packed with bonus printed matter like art prints, stickers and random tables.
It’s all paper stuff, but I think it’s gonna feel pretty special.
Any ’game content’ (such as random tables) will be available to all as a digital download.

Accessibility
Like Artefact and Orbital, the digital edition will also be fully-compatible with screen readers. A second version will also be provided to support a range of visual processing needs. Once again, Yubi will be handling the accessibility design of the digital files.

Community Copies
Every backer of Bucket of Bolts, physical or digital, will also be contributing one digital copy of the game to be available for free for those who need it. Thanks!

Stretch Goals
This is intentionally designed as a small project, but I've still got some cool things to announce if we break past our funding goal :)

Delivery.
Timelines
I’ve got a draft of the game written, and I’m happy that the core concept works as well for spaceships as it did for magical items (after making a few changes to the design). I’m hoping to get a playtest version out in a month or two, with the full digital version being delivered in late spring/early summer and the physical edition following soon after.

BackerKit
As with my previous projects, I’ll be using BackerKit to manage fulfilment. This time, though, I’m collecting shipping fees through Kickstarter so you shouldn’t need to add funds in BackerKit unless you’ve selected add-ons.

Orbital 
Orbital header art
My previous project, Orbital, is going to print imminently which means that the bulk of the work for that Kickstarter is done. I’m not shipping out the rewards myself, and the stretch goal content is coming along nicely. I’ll continue to actively manage the project, but barring any catastrophes it shouldn’t take up much headspace.

ARTEFACT: Reviews & Remarks.
I’m so happy with the way Artefact has been received. Here’s hoping I can recapture some of that magic for Bucket of Bolts.
If you’re a returning backer: hi, nice to see you again! I hope you also enjoyed Artefact :)
Print copies of Artefact
"It combines a little bit of writing and a little bit of drawing with a lot of storytelling to make a game that is one of the most relaxing and mindful experiences I have had this year." - Shut Up & Sit Down
"This is a great system agnostic supplement that could fit on any gamer’s shelf". — Pulp Culture Museum
"It was a wonderful game that once I started, I had a hard time putting down. I probably spent 8-9 hours on the game over the course of a quarantined weekend, and ended up with a story that pulled at my own heart-strings." — Play Every Role
There are also lots of lovely comments on the game's itch.io page.
~
Thanks for reading!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This is my third project now, so I'm getting pretty confident in successfully delivering rewards. I've intentionally pitched a smaller-scale project this time, to fit around my existing life commitments. I'm using familiar software, processes and people, so there shouldn't be any surprises.

During the delivery of my first two projects there's been a global pandemic, Brexit, sabotage of the USPS and international mail strikes. We've also welcomed the arrival of a second child into our family. We've figured it out. I think barring any serious family issues, we'll be fine. And, as always, you can expect a minimum of one update a month, keeping you in the loop.

The Trans Rage Trilogy is a group of three zines written and produced by me, Lara Turner of Glaive Guisarme Games. 
 Let's Rob RJ McElhenny and Steal Her Golden Quill: A wish-fulfillment heist that pits  wizards against a young-adult fantasy author.
 Penis 2.0.77 -or- A Genital Customization Game Roughly a Billion Times more Cyberpunk Than That Other One, Written by an Honest-to-Goodness Trans Woman Who Didn't Even Work Weekends: Exactly what it sounds like.
 To Stand Before the Dragon's Wrath: A quick, narrative story game that pits you (yes, you!) against the dragon who has been forcing you to live under their regime. 
I'm celebrating ZineQuest by releasing physical copies of my angriest, transiest games, and (because it's ZineQuest 3, baybee!) adding in a revised and updated zine-formed version of a game I wrote back when I thought I was a boy, and have only now recognized the Big Trans Energy coming from. 
Look at these furious zines!
Heck yeah! There's more details about the individual games below, but first let's talk about the broad details.
My goal is to take three games that bring me great joy, and send as many copies as possible out into the world. Maybe they'll get played? Maybe they'll change lives? Or maybe they'll get picked up by another trans person who will have a little chuckle about the shared understanding of it all. These are all great outcomes! 
As a backer at the $10 level, you will get digital copies of all three zines; each is sixteen-pages, black and white, and set up for both A4 and 8.5"x11" paper, sent straight to your digital doorstep at the end of the campaign, along with screen-readable copies. In addition, you will get immediate access to the betas of all three zines! These are 99% done, but may be subject to final layout and word tweaking. 
At the $20 level you get the good stuff: a physical copy of any zine! Choose whichever one makes you feel most euphoric. And hey, you still get the digital copies immediately, so you can read them all and pick your favorite at the end of the campaign when I send out the surveys. 
And if you pledge $40, you get the entire trilogy. That's right, if you're going to buy two, you get the third one for free, whether you want it or not! This is my real goal here, getting you wonderful folks out there get a full triple-barreled blast of my Feelings. 
This is a strictly one-woman affair, so that means I will be printing these out on my very own home laser printer, stapling them with my very own longarm stapler, and sending them to you through the United States Postal Service, First Class Mail. 
I'm Lara! This is the fourth time I've launched a Kickstarter, but the first time I've done so as an out-and-proud transgirl (with the previous three having been run in states of "completely in the closet," "completely in denial," and "completely oblivious"). There's a fun rule-of-3 going on here, isn't there? I kickstarted 3 games as Ed, and now I'm doing 3 more as Lara, right here on ZineQuest 3! 
ANYWAY. In addition to being trans, I'm a professional tabletop game developer; I've published a bunch of indies as Glaive Guisarme Games, but also worked professionally on a number of games, including Acute Paranoia for Mongoose Publishing, Eldritch Century for Draco Studios, and bunch of games for Evil Hat Productions who were the first to put my real name on a game, Fate Condensed. 
I came out six months ago. It was very dramatic. It's been a rough six months in a lot of ways, but on the whole, even when I'm miserable, I've never been happier. Highly recommended. 
Okay, okay, let's take a look at the three games that make up the Trans Rage Trilogy.
You have, for some time, had a bone to pick with RJ McElhenny, author of a series of extremely popular young-adult fantasy novels, but lately she's been saying extremely reductive things about who she thinks deserves to be called a wizard. So, as a bunch of magic-users who she would describe as "it's okay for them to call themselves wizards but they're not really wizards," you're going to heist the hell out of her mansion. 
Let's Rob RJ McElhenny and Steal Her Golden Quill is the "angry" part of trans rage. Fuck politeness, let's smash some shit.
Inspired by an author whose name I currently forget, this here is a wish-fulfillment magic heist. Move through the randomly-generated rooms of McElhenny Manor and confront the obstacles she's thrown in your way with your awesome magic powers (which is to say, describe how cool you are and chuck some dice to see if it's cool enough or if you have to describe an even more awesome spell). If you start running low on magic energy, talk about how mad you are at McElhenny and you'll be ready to take on another room. 
This game was originally released in July of 2020, because That Author was in the public sphere for some reason or another and I was full of feelings that I wasn't quite sure how to express. It would be nice if this game were to stop being relevant, but I just learned she's going to be drawing paychecks for a TV show that's gonna keep her in the public sphere and frankly it looks like "getting mad at That Author" is a pretty evergreen situation. Blech. Anyway. This re-release includes:
Revised rules, including replacing "flashbacks" with a simpler, quicker method of regaining Action dice
Cleaned-up layout and a prettier cover 
My actual name on it because when I first released it I wasn't out yet and didn't know whaaaaat to put on it
This is a handsome sixteen-page zine, black ink on off-white paper (the most maaaaagical color of paper), folded, stapled, and delivered to your door so you can perform your own magic revenge. 
Get this one if you want to feel like a real cool wizard doing some cool crimes with your wizard buddies.
Welcome to the cyber-future, chummer. Is it everything you wanted it to be? Has all the hype really given way to a fully-realized universe with acceptable levels of optimization and a minimum of crashes? The streets are lawless, the corps own your soul, and "hope" has lost all meaning, but it's a sweet-ass transhumanist future so even if you don't have control of your life, you still have control of your sex and gender. Probably got a hell of a menu to choose from, right?
Penis 2.0.77 is the "manic" part of trans rage. Nothing makes sense, so make it your own and giggle at the absurdity.
Inspired by a popular AAA video game that had (and let us be extremely generous here) mixed results in its depictions of trans people. This is as far as I can tell, the most complex and full-featured series of crotch-related tables ever put into a zine. There's no other "game" here, but there are lots of bad jokes about wobbly bits. Written in a fugue state late in 2020, I have a few regrets about the initial presentation. Most notably, I accidentally aped the last few centuries of male-dominated medical research by almost totally discounting the clitoris. This revision remedies that, and includes:
More genital variables, taking us up to approximately 4 trillion different configurations
Parts synergies, which will make random crotches hew slightly closer to "expected" without hampering custom design potential
Re-balanced parts costs, to prevent you from accruing too much MegaCorp MegaDebt
For the purposes of transparency, especially with respect to "what you can and cannot launch a Kickstarter for," let me be clear: there is no pornography here. There are no photos or drawings of nude people or anatomical features, nor anything that could be considered "erotica." It's charts with crotch jokes, and RPG jokes, and cyberpunk jokes. You can create a character (sort of) but the real goal here is cathartic giggling about the inherent strangeness of the human underwear-zone. 
This is a totally cyber sixteen-page zine, printed in black on light blue paper (the color of the digital cyberscape here in Byte City). Finally, you can create those aspirational genitals you've been dreaming of.
Get this one if you want jokes on jokes on jokes, or to delight in overly-laborious random roll chargen.
One day, the dragon crawled out of myth and into the real world. Our real world. It seized control, and bent the people to its will... yourself included. But you have resisted, despite everything you've lost. And now it's time to fight back. This is a fast-paced storytelling game that puts you in the position of... yourself. Not a hero, not a warrior, but your own real-world self, using your own real-world skills to fight a seemingly unstoppable force. You might not win... you probably won't. But you have to try.
To Stand Before the Dragon's Wrath is the "resigned" part of trans rage. You probably can't fix anything, but you're going to have to try.
Way back in the forgotten history of our benighted planet, almost a decade ago, a boy named Edward wrote a game which he thought was about cool dragon fights, but which was actually about being upset at a world which was wrong in an way he wished he could put a face on. He found himself living half for reasons he didn't really understand and in his heart of hearts he wished that he had the power to take on the powers that be.
What a dipshit this boy named Ed was. How obvious in retrospect were his works. Let me guess, Edward, if you had a superpower, it would have been shapeshifting? Perhaps you don't think much of vanity and take a grim pride in not caring about your appearance? Oh who's your favorite character on this show, is it the fairly butch lady who cleans up nice? You fool, you transparent buffoon. 
AHEM. This revised and re-imagined version maintains the same broad structure as the one-page original, but includes:
Revised text to simplify and clarify the main mechanics 
Bonus content related to altering the game now included in the main text, rather than some separate pages
Subtext now more obvious, especially to me, the author
There will be a dragon making your lives miserable and you, the players portraying lightly fictionalized versions of yourself, will talk about how it's made you miserable, and then attempt to take out that dragon with your own unique skills. In other words, you'll give the aspects of society that make you miserable a big scaly face, and then punch it. You're likely to get horribly defeated in the process, but, and this is important, you might not! 
The storytelling system uses simple card draws and light risk-reward mechanisms to tell grandiose stories of epic battles, and the whole thing is being released for the first time as a sixteen-page zine, black ink on pink paper (the color of fierceness, flames, and blood, but without getting so dark that it would be hard to read), complete with additional information on how to adapt and modify the core engine to your own ends. 
Get this one if you want a light-but-robust storytelling engine about confronting enormous odds.
Bonus Content
It's like stretch goals, but I was always going to do them anyway. It's just nice to announce them at the same time as some major monetary milestone. 
Each zine comes with its own special single-sheet bonus, delivered with every physical copy. Get the three-pack, get three bonuses! 
To Stand Before the Dragon's Wrath (Pocket Edition) - Included with the full Wrath, it's an especially tiny version of the basic game. No frills, no variants, just a small package which you can easily tuck into a pocket and take with you to conventions (when conventions exist again).
Anthony Charterstone and the Unwelcome Intruder dust jacket - The cover of RJ McElhenny's most recent novel. If you aren't quite mad enough at her to steal her golden quill, then you can simply read through her works and allow the rage to bubble up within. 
Penis 2.0.77 Genital Customization Form - A closed envelope containing a character sheet filled out with my own personal genital information, as accurately reflected as I could make it. Importantly, you have no right to this information, but I won't stop you from opening it. Do you respect trans people enough to not give in to prurient curiosity about their genitalia? 
Interview with PlusOneExp
If you want to hear me talk a little bit more about this campaign, why I made it, and what I'm hoping to get out of it, check out my interview with Tony of PlusOneExp!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This will be my fourth Kickstarter; each of the previous ones was successfully funded and delivered to backers. In particular, this is the second time I will be running a ZineQuest Kickstarter. As was the case then, the games are already feature-complete; the only thing I need to do is a final revision pass and a layout that fits A4 paper. The printing and shipping will be entirely under my control: these games are getting printed on my home printer, folded by my exquisitely-manicured hands, and handed off to the folks at my local post office.

Last time I said that the only conceivable delay would come from a complete breakdown of the postal service. Ha hah, how I laughed to think of the solid, dependable USPS coming to harm. And then COVID happened and the postal service ground to a halt. I am not tempting fate this time! It turns out, large scale disasters can and do happen.

That being said, the risks associated with this project are the ones that apply to all projects: illness or injury, major disaster. It's ZineQuest; the stakes are purposefully quite low.

updates.update_userinfo: Spreading the Love on Valentine's Day!
updates.update_content:
Valentine’s Day can be a daunting proposition for folks who have a, shall we say, complicated history of loving their bodies and themselves. I hope all y'all are keeping yourselves well today. 
Happy V, everyone. So it should go without saying that my valentine is all of the wonderful little goofs who backed me. You are the collective winds beneath my wings. I thought one thing I could do to celebrate is to spread the love around a bit; instead of talking about myself ad infinitum, I could share some of the other Zine Quest games that I’m currently excited about.

CDProjekt Red’s Cyberpunk 2077. Sort of a big deal in video games! I had zero interest in playing it as we approached its release. Too big, too violent, too overhyped, and yeah, its trans representation thus far had been… well. There are plenty of places you can read about Cyberpunk 2077’s, shall we say, problematic take on trans issues. More eloquent minds than mine have talked about the Chromanticore controversy, where CP77’s marketing featured an in-universe ad that heavily-sexualized a trans woman with a huge dick.

Friends! You have had a day’s respite from my Emotional Ramblings, but now I’m back to ask the question that’s on all of our minds: just what popular children’s fantasy author is RJ McElhenny meant to be a parody of, anyway?
… what you really don't know? Gotta say, that leaves me Just Kinda Reeling from surprise. Well, I don't want dirty my fingertips by taping her name (and also who wants to risk attracting the attention of fans and defenders) so I'll just call her That Author for the time being.

I cannot believe that the penis game didn’t win the poll. I’m not complaining, mind, I guess I just assumed my followers were a bunch of puerile goobers, when in fact, as the numbers have it, they’re dragon fans. OH NO does this mean I'm the puerile goober? 
... no. No that can't be. 
ANYWAY as promised, it's the first of three Self-Indulgent Mini-Essays. Stick around for (or skip to) the end when I reveal a piece of Bonus Content for this campaign!

So I was GONNA do a thing where I posted a screenshot where I was all like "OMG I'm almost at a thousand! You all rock!" and then a Mysterious Benefactor emerged from the faewilds to tip me over the edge. So... woo! Thanks mysterious benefactor, whoe'er you might be...

campaign.story:
The Burning of Carbex is a ~100-page three-act campaign compatible with the Mothership Sci-Fi Horror Roleplaying Game. A malevolent alien parasite has been freed and seeks to spread its corrupting influence far and wide.

Carbex was once covered in lush forests, before the fire. Everything burned, except for some silverfish-like insects who fled underground. Millenia later, coal miners break into their refuge. 

About a week later, you are contacted by a nearby law enforcement agency. The Angelus Fabrica Station orbiting Carbex issued an automated distress signal after deploying every escape pod. 4 days of communication attempts without response met the persistent distress signal. The agency offers you a decent sum to determine the complete evacuation’s rationale and to rescue and assist, by any means necessary any remaining crew members. The Angelus Fabrica is a disaster, most of its residents having been killed or altered by the strange transformations these parasites affect in their hosts, The Creeping Perforation.
Results- somewhat typical
Meanwhile, another disaster is careening towards a much larger population, the Sineto Chem Solutions Deep Space Factory. On Carbex, deep within Sediment Hill coal mine, the parasites have coalesced horrifyingly and their minions are planning to spread across the stars. Want to play almost all of Act I? Here you go, just know it's still a work in progress.
Anyone else's ear itch right now?
6 new enemies and a template to make any lifeform a monstrosity.
3 locations to explore (A stricken refinery station, an overrun ship, and an infested coal mine.)
A new station, the Sineto Chem Solutions Deep Space Factory, to defend or add to any existing campaign 
20 Artifacts to find and use in your campaigns
A story branch that will affect the next chapter of the story depending on which you choose to pursue
Story hooks and opportunities for extended play
And plenty of hardship. And fire.

campaign.story:
The Drain is a tense level-0 funnel adventure for the Mothership Sci-Fi Horror RPG set in a combat-ravaged farming habitat.
Each player runs 4-5 level-0 prisoner-soldiers through the hellish battlefield of the colony ship Within Wheels. Their mission: win freedom by acquiring a legendary religious relic at the behest of their corporate jailors, PrayCo. 
The Wheel's hollow internal landscape of barren fields and rusting, bombed out structures swarm with monstrous bioengineered animals and lethal corporate relic hunters. Trenches, minefields, hull punctures and a stalemated battle bar passage from the high-gravity docking bays to the blasphemous prize waiting at the funnel's tip.
Simple farmers of the rotating colony ship Within Wheels starve as bargain InstaCrops wither on the vine. They turn to faith and ritual, concocting visions of a hell on earth from half-remembered traditions and commercialized lore. Bunker doors seal as their beacon calls upon believers to consecrate synthetic soil with holy blood.
The Drain takes a WWI influenced war-as-hell meat grinder and mashes it with bleak, occult survival horror themes drawn from video games like Silent Hill, Resident Evil, and Darkwood. This 16-page zine is packed with everything you need to churn out a crop of battle hardened level-1 characters from level-0 rabble, including:
 Brand new rules for running carnage-filled funnels in Mothership.
 A funnel crawl map by Andrew Walter, gorgeously illuminated to chart the party's movement through the conical space.
 Vicious new items to arm your mob of funnel PCs.
 Art on every spread, including illustrations from Mothership creator Sean McCoy.

This module emulates Dungeon Crawl Classics’ "funnel" character generation in which each player pilots multiple level-0 characters through a "meat grinder". Survivors, forged in blood, earn their 1st level. If embraced, a funnel becomes a contest to achieve the most spectacular PC death. Players and GMs bond in murderous collaboration, anxieties surrounding character death melting away. PCs become resources to throw at problems rather than precious things to be guarded. Campaign-spanning legends of heroic sacrifice and bitter survival begin here.
All backers will receive a 1-page PDF of my funnel rules for Mothership immediately after the campaign ends so you can get started running your own funnels. The rules sheet will include guidelines for creating your own funnel adventures and running existing modules as funnels.
Interested in a writing sample from the author before you back? My first Mothership pamphlet and Gold DriveThruRPG bestseller Moonbase Blues is free for the duration of this Kickstarter. Snag it if you haven't already!
https://ian-yusem.itch.io/moonbase-blues
Funnel Survivor backers will receive a limited run double-sided A3 poster of Andrew Walter's map for The Drain. I will hand write custom, unique game content for each backer on the "secret" reverse side. Backers will submit a personal theme and work with me to customize Within Wheels for their home game. The content I write is up to each backer, and could vary from a gut-churning table to a terrifying new monster.
Pretty cool video, right? You could own all 3 unique, lovingly handcrafted spaceship models from the trailer to use as props in your game. Should you back at the Within Wheels pledge tier, you will receive: A 5" x 3" model of the ill-fated sleeve soldier dropship Genesis, a 12" x 9" model of the PrayCo prison transport Charity, and a 9" x 4" model of colony ship and adventure setting Within Wheels delivered right to your home (shipping included). The models were made with styrene foam, superglue, "bits of junk", blood, sweat, tears, and dreams. The proceeds for this pledge will go to Meredith, our steadfast video producer and master modeler.
Ian Yusem: Pamphlet baron and occasional RPG blogger, Ian (myself) is the author and publisher of The Drain. Mothership fans might recognize some of my 3rd party scenarios like Moonbase Blues and Dinoplex: Cataclysm. I think The Drain is my best work yet, and I'm excited to send it out into the world.
Christian Kessler: The layout and design genius behind books like Silent Titans and Troika! Numinous Edition is putting his eminent talents behind this humble zine. Christian also illustrated the sweet, Russian constructivism-influenced cover art for The Drain. A man of many talents.
Fiona Maeve Geist: Editing powerhouse and RPG darling, Fiona has been essential to this project's development and she's done a wonderful job tightening up the manuscript. Fiona is a lead developer on Mothership and takes her pen to 99% of everything good in RPGs as part of the editing team MoonRat Conspiracy, including Ultraviolet Grasslands, Troika, Silent Titans, ad infinitum.
Andrew Walter: Andrew made the best damn map I've ever seen in an RPG for this project. You used to know his illustrations from beloved titles like Troika, Slipgate Chokepoint and Fever Swamp—now you know him from The Drain.
Sean McCoy: Last, but certainly not least, the design legend behind Mothership and co-owner of Tuesday Knight Games is contributing an absolute ton of fantastically horrifying art to this zine. Not a spread will go by without its splendor.
The Drain's manuscript is written, playtested, and edited. Christian is underway on final layout and the last pieces of art are rolling in from Sean. We're on track to fulfill well before our June estimate (which budgets an extra couple months for unseen complications). Here's a conservative timeline laying out our internal milestones:
January 2021 - Writing, playtesting, editing complete
February 2021 - Kickstarter campaign, PledgeManager opened to Backers
March 2021 - All art submitted, layout and text finalized
April 2021 - Printed proofs ordered and reviewed
May 2021 - Print run ordered, stretch goals completed
June 2021 - Fulfillment begins
